Sir:

I beg to report that I received an urgent call from Squamish Residential School and found that the sewage system was completely blocked, and overflowing. There was no time to obtain authority to have repairs made before starting work on it, as the situation is serious. I have employed men to open up the system and make the necessary repairs under the supervision of the school caretaker, who has a thorough knowledge of the layout of the system, as he was present when it was installed.

A further report will be sent later, but I presume the Department will not object to the work being commenced without first obtaining authority. It may be only a day or two's work, but it may be more extensive as it is impossible to locate the stoppage without uncovering the pipes. If near the school, a day or two will suffice, but it may be anywhere within 200 yards where it connects with the City system.

It is probably caused by roots, as the City of North Vancouver is having similar trouble elsewhere.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

B/DH.

Sir:

With further reference to my letter of the 10th instant regarding the trouble with the sewage system at Squamish Residential School, I have had this opened up, and it is easy to see the cause of the trouble.

There are two pipes - one from the girls' side and one from the boys' side - and these are both 6" in diameter. They are joined to one 4" pipe, which connects with the sewer. The remarkable thing is that such an error has not caused trouble before.

It is necessary to renew 130 feet of the four-inch pipe with 6" vitrified pipe, and I am having this done pending your approval, as it is absolutely necessary and cannot be delayed awaiting authority.

I trust this will be approved, under the circumstances.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa,
June 20, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 12th instant with reference to the sewage system at the Squamish residential school.

It was not found possible to include any specific amount in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at this school. Under these circumstances the Department cannot pay for the expenditure caused by improving the sewage system. This will have to be provided by the school management.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

F.J.C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
416 Federal Bldg.,
Vancouver, B. C.
Sir:

I beg to refer to my reports of June 10th and 12th regarding the stoppage in the sewage system at Squamish Residential School. After opening it up, we have found it more serious than anticipated, not only was the pipe too small but it was laid in a criminally inefficient manner. Instead of being straight, there were curves around every rock. The joints were not cemented, and the roots have bunched up inside the pipes. The health authorities gave us until today to get the water running, and this was done last evening. Two man-holes have to be built, and 180 feet of pipe renewed.

It is twelve feet below ground at one end and four feet at the other. On account of wet weather, the trench began to cave in and had to be shored up. I was able to get an expert in this line of work, who is highly recommended by the North Vancouver engineering department - Mr. Piper, who is doing a good job.

No Indians are available for digging, there is not one able-bodied Indian on the Reserve unemployed, so white men are doing the work. They request some pay as they have now worked during a period of eight days from the 10th to the 17th as follows:

$106.30

I have the honour to be,

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th instant regarding repairs to the sewage system at Squamish Indian Residential School.

The Department does not appear to realize that this work is an emergency. The sewage system was completely blocked up, and the effluvia at the School was not only unpleasant, but a distinct warning, and for the protection of the pupils and staff at the school, something had to be done immediately - otherwise there was grave danger of an epidemic which could easily have had tragic consequences among these small children. The health authorities also notified us that conditions were bad, and with all these warnings we should have found ourselves in an inevitable position with the public and press had an epidemic occurred.

I quite understand that no specific amount in the current year's appropriation was made for repairs at this school, and no request would have been made for any amount. This was something unforeseen, and came as an unpleasant surprise.

I considered it my duty to have the situation remedied immediately as common humanity demanded that it be done. Most of the work is outside the school property, as shown on the attached sketch, and the school authorities say they are quite unable to pay for the work from their grant, which is only sufficient to feed and clothe the children.

I hope the Department will re-consider this matter at as early a date as possible - the workmen are clamouring for their pay. No Indians were available to do the work even if they had been able, but it required an experienced man to construct the manholes and do the necessary pipe work.

An early reply will be appreciated as it is not pleasant to deal with men who think they are being refused their wages.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

(P.J.C. Ball)

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

AIR MAIL
Sir:

re: File No.167-1-5

With further reference to your letter of the 24th ultimo and other correspondence in connection with the repairs to Squamish Residential School sewage, the Department is responsible for this expense and not the school authorities.

I have gone further into the matter, and find that the school formerly had a septic tank, and it is claimed that they never experienced any trouble, but when the Auditorium was built in 1927, the school was connected by the builder of the auditorium with their system, and against the wishes of the school at that time. This accounts for the shoddy work on the pipes where they connected two six-inch pipes with a four-inch main and did not even cement the joints. This was in line with the rest of the work at the Auditorium, but was to be expected when such a person as Andrew Pauli was appointed "building inspector". The School authorities are in no way responsible for present conditions, and the liability is entirely that of the Department.

I trust the matter will be immediately reconsidered in the light of this further information, and the labour and material paid for.

In addition to the previous list of wages earned, as shown in my letter of June 21st, the following additional work has been done, which completes the job:

| Name       | Hours | Rate | Total |
|------------|-------|------|-------|
| T. Piper   | 68    | $0.60| $40.80|
| P. Hanlon  | 74    | $0.52| $38.52|
| J. Beck    | 63    | $0.57| $28.57|
| F. Terrillion | 62 | $0.52| $32.12|
| M. Goumain | 72    | $0.40| $28.40|

I wish to point out that I wrote you on the 10th of June by air mail, which letter must have been received by the 11th or 12th, notifying you that the sewage system was blocked, that I was having the pipes opened up, that it might be an extensive job, and I asked if you objected to my having the work done. On June 12th I again reported about the work, asking for approval; on the 21st I reported further, and you did not write until June 20th refusing to pay for it. As the reports I sent were by air mail, I consider the Department should have notified me on the 11th or 12th at the latest that you would not pay the cost, and I should then, of course, stopped the work, and declined to accept further responsibility, although I think an outbreak of typhoid would have cost considerably more than these repairs.

I regret that I have to disagree with the Department's decision in this matter. The present situation is
that both the Department and the School disclaim responsibility, and the cost of labour and material are unpaid; the workmen are demanding their wages, and no funds are available here to pay them. I do not know what the next step will be, but the workmen will probably commence some kind of action.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

B/DH.

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.

AIR MAIL.
Ottawa,
July 8th., 1939

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of June 29th., and July 4th., in connection with repairs to the sewage system at the Squamish Residential School.

As you were informed in official letter of the 20th. ultimo, it was not found possible to include any specific amount in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at this school. The Department is therefore unable to consider payment of the expenditure involved in repairing the sewage system.

In view of the fact that it has been decided that no further deductions will be made from the per capita allowances of Residential Schools, the management of the Squamish School will receive an amount $125.00, which was deducted from their March quarter earnings. This amount will be paid when issuing check for the June quarter grant. In addition there will be no deduction from the June quarter, consequently, the school management should have sufficient funds to pay for the expenses in connection with the sewage system.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. Welfare & Training.

F. J. C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
416 Federal Building,
Vancouver, B. C.
Sir:

re: File No.167-1-5

With reference to your decision not to pay the expenses of repairing the sewage works leading from Squamish Residential School, I have received a telephone call this morning from Mr.Goumain saying that the workmen are going to sue for their wages - against whom, I do not know. If against me, I do not feel that I should employ counsel at my own expense. Personally, I do not see how provision could have been made in advance for emergency expense, such as this, which could not possibly be foreseen.

The school authorities have a clear case, as it was not the Residential School system which was blocked but the pipes laid when the auditorium was built. The auditorium is the day school, and the Residential School is a separate building, which belongs to the Order of the Sisters of the Child Jesus.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

B/DH.

(F.J.C.Ball)
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa,
July 26, 1939.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

In a letter dated June 12 Indian Agent Ball wrote to the Department stating that the sewage system at the Squamish residential school was causing trouble and that he had already authorized the necessary work. In subsequent letters dated June 21, June 29 and July 4 he wrote to us again in connection with this matter and in each of these letters referred to the Squamish residential school.

In the meantime we had advised him that as no funds were specifically provided in our appropriation for expenditure at the Squamish residential school during the present fiscal year it was impossible for us to consider payment of the expenditure for repairing the sewage system. Our reason for making this statement was that this is a Church-owned school and present regulations require us to secure an Order-in-Council for all expenditures at Church-owned schools and only those Church-owned schools that are specially mentioned in the Order-in-Council can be considered for expenditures. As no request had been received when we were preparing our estimates for any expenditure at the Squamish residential school it naturally followed that this school was not specially mentioned in the Order-in-Council secured this year. We intimated this to Mr. Ball but from the tone of some of his letters it would appear that he considers we are simply trying to ignore him. This is certainly not the case. I think you will realize that we have our own difficulties and certainly in the present instance it was not possible to authorize any expenditure at the Squamish residential school due to the reasons stated above.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
After all the letters he wrote to us he has now forwarded another letter dated July 15 stating that the sewage work was actually in connection with the Squamish day school although, as pointed out above, his other letters mentioned Squamish residential school. We can make expenditures at Squamish day school because this is considered in our records as Departmental property. Under these circumstances we are arranging to forward an accountable cheque for $163.42.

I wish you would explain this matter to Mr. Ball.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

AGENT'S REPORT ON VANCOUVER AGENCY FOR JUNE 1939.

On the 9th, the Sisters at Squamish Residential School reported a blockage in the sewage system at the school and work was commenced immediately as the health authorities notified us conditions were unsatisfactory.

The Department has refused to support my action in this matter, and refused to pay the expense. What are an Agent's duties in such matters?

F. J. C. Ball,
Indian Agent.
Sir:

I have the honour to report a matter to you personally, the necessity for so doing being regretted, but the Welfare & Training Branch does not appear to realise the serious situation.

The facts are briefly as follows, and have been reported to the Department on the following dates - June 10th (air-mail), June 12th, June 21st (air-mail), June 29th, July 4th and July 15th:

On June 10th the Squamish Residential School caretaker phoned me to go over and advise them as the sewage system was blocked and the health authorities had reported that the effluvia was most marked. I investigated and immediately wrote the Department by air mail that it was necessary to employ someone to open up the system and asking for the necessary authority. On the 12th we found the blockage more serious than expected and I again reported to the Department, following it with further reports on the 21st and 29th of June. Absolutely no attention whatever was paid to my requests or June 10th and 12th for authority to do the work and until the 26th June was any reply received, and then a letter, dated June 26th, by ordinary mail, arrived with the information that it was not found possible to include any specific amount in the current year's appropriation for repairs and improvements at this School. Under these circumstances, the Department cannot pay for the expenditure caused by improving the sewage system."

This borders on the ridiculous as no one could possibly have foretold that the sewage system would be blocked on June 10th 1939, and the work being done was not "improvement" but a vital necessity to safeguard health and possibly lives. What would have been the situation if I had done nothing and an outbreak of typhoid had occurred, as it might easily have done? What are an Agent's duties, if not to attend to such matters?

I strongly object to the Department ignoring my requests of June 10th and subsequent dates, by air-mail, for authority to do the work and waiting until the work was finished before saying they would not pay for it. I should have been advised on June 11th by air-mail or telegram that the Department would not pay for the labour and materials, and I should have stopped all work, and allowed matters to take their own course. It was grossly unfair to wait until the work was done and then refuse to pay for it, and such treatment is totally foreign to the usual custom of the Department.

I received a further letter, File No.167-1-5, dated July 8th repeating that the Department is unable to consider
payment of the expenditure and apparently expecting the School to do so. This they rightly refuse, as the blockage was found between the school system and the municipal sewer. The school formerly had their own septic tanks with 6-inch pipes from the boys' and girls' sides of the school, but many years ago the Department, against the wishes of the School, had connected them with the sewer; and in so doing had connected two six-inch pipes to one of four inches, and it is amazing that such an arrangement has not been blocked sooner.

The situation now is that the workmen are threatening suit for their wages and nothing has been paid either for labour or material.

I do not see what other action I could have taken and am quite sure I should have merited censure if I had not protected the Department from public criticism and possible action by the health authorities. The School is in the Municipality of North Vancouver, surrounded by residences of white people, and the situation was one requiring prompt action, and I was entitled to different treatment from the Department.

Surely provision is made in all estimates for emergencies of this kind, and it is no excuse to say that provision was not made for such work in this instance.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

B/DH.

(F.J.C.Ball)
Indian Agent.

HAROLD W. MCGILL, Esq., M.D.
Director of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

I enclose, for your information, a copy of a letter dated October 6 received from Indian Agent Ball.

It is difficult to understand why Agent Ball has requested the Band to pass the resolution which has been forwarded to us. I make this statement in view of the fact that in all previous correspondence Mr. Ball has insisted that the expenditure in connection with the repairs to the sewage system was the responsibility of the Department. We have already paid the following amounts:

Labour .................................. $163.42
Material .................................. 124.33

In addition to the above the following accounts have just reached us:

City Treasurer, Corporation of North Vancouver, for connection of sewer of Squamish Indian Reserve $52.22

Account for wages on sewer for period June 10 to 17 ............... 106.50

The two last-mentioned accounts have not yet been paid nor will consideration be given to them until your reply is received.

Please review this matter with Mr. Ball and let me know definitely whether you consider the repairs

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
to the sewage system are a fair charge against the Band funds as I think you were previously advised that if these repairs were necessary for the Squamish day school the Department is prepared to assume them although Mr. Ball should be very definitely informed that if he incurs expenditure in future without securing authority the Department will be unable to favourably consider any payment.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Dear Sir:

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of October 17th in the matter of expenditures incurred by Mr. Indian Agent Ball for repairs to the sewerage system serving the North Vancouver (Squamish) Indian Residential and Day Schools.

I have inquired into this matter, as instructed, and found that the section of the system repaired runs along one of the main roads through the village along which new Indian houses have recently been constructed. In all probability these dwellings will in time be connected to this system, and as the Indians consider they have a right to do this I do not see why their funds should not, to some extent, be used to meet the costs of maintenance. In my opinion the two last accounts submitted by Mr. Ball, i.e., $52.55 and $106.50, covered by resolution of the Band, would be a fair charge against the Band Funds, and I would recommend they be so charged.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

AGENT'S REPORT ON VANCOUVER AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JUNE 1940.

I visited Squamish Residential school on the 3rd. Two new fire escapes will be built during the summer holidays as an added precaution. On Sunday the 9th I received a wire from Father Cornell saying I was urgently needed at Sechelt school. This proved to be in connection with pupils leaving school to rejoin their parents in Washington where they were berrypicking. One does not know what a wire of that kind may mean, especially one arriving on Sunday and I could not contact the school to find out whether there was serious trouble there. I managed to get there but felt that the need was not so urgent as the wire indicated.

F. J. C. Ball.
Indian Agent.
Sir:

I beg to advise that the Squamish Residential School has requested some lumber to build 7 seats in the dining room of the School, the seats to be made in the manual training department of the School as part of the instruction.

The lumber and nails, including delivery to the school, would cost less than $15.00, as edge-grain fir of good quality is required, and, of course, there would be no cost for labour.

If the Department can authorize this expense, the Reverend Principal will appreciate it.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

(F.J.C.Ball)
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Sir:

AIR RAID PRECAUTIONS

Little more can be done on the Reserves except fire prevention. If there are many fires in North Vancouver, the Reserve will be left to do its own fire-fighting. We have two hydrants on Squamish Reserve No.1, but no hose, the North Vancouver City Fire Department has attended to any fires on the Reserve. The Indians now need two more hydrants, hose and a small hose reel, 6 shovels and 2 axes. I would mention here that the large Church is on the Reserve in the middle of the village, and our fire insurance policy would not cover "enemy action".

Fred, J.C. Ball,
Indian Agent

Sir:

I have the honour to report that I sent a letter dated the 11th instant to the Department regarding air raid precaution on Squamish Reserve, also a report on the construction of air raid shelters at the Squamish Residential School.

Today I receive a copy of a letter dated December 16th, File No. 167-1-5, to the Indian Commissioner, which treats me personally as non-existent as Agent.

Fred J.G. Ball,
Indian Agent.
Sir:

I beg to report that damage to the extent of $70.00 was done to school property at Squamish Indian Residential School on Hallowe'en night last year, and although every effort has been made to locate the offenders, we have been unsuccessful. The school caretaker gave me the names of four boys who, he said, were implicated, but they were all able to prove definitely that they were at home hours before the damage was done, and did not leave their homes until the next day.

One of the drinking fountains in the school grounds was damaged to the extent of $10.00, the rest of the damage being to buildings and fences.

The Sister Superior requests that we assist in repairing this damage, and has asked me to write you for your advice.

The drinking fountain is one of the two which the Department installed some years ago. A flag pole was cut down and fences broken, besides damage to buildings. I respectfully request that at least part of the expense be paid. The Sister Superior has made many improvements to the school at her own expense, when they have been suggested to her, and recently installed new fire escapes, and I hope the Department will see its way clear to accede to this request.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

B/DH.

I would ask you to look over the amounts allowed to this school in the past few years, as I believe you will find them most moderate. The Sisters have done considerable work on the School without asking us for assistance. Admittedly the building does not belong to us, but other schools in the same category have received considerable assistance. Having in view the above circumstances, will you kindly advise me whether I may apply through the usual channels for payment of this account by the Department?

Ottawa, April 15th, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

We have your letter of the 9th instant with reference to painting the exterior of the Squamish Residential School.

In the appropriation for the fiscal year 1947-48 we have provided an amount of $500. for new equipment, repairs and improvements at this school.

We have no objection to the amount being used for repainting the exterior of the building, if this is considered the most urgent work.

However, the school should understand that if the money is used for this particular purpose, no other funds will be available for repairs and improvements and the purchase of new equipment during the current fiscal year.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your 3411 of the 5th instant, enclosing the December quarter return of the Squamish Indian Residential School.

The death of Teresa Peter - No. 0134, is regretted.

The name of Edward Corkill - No. 118, was shown on the September quarter return but does not appear on the December quarter return, although no application has been received for his discharge.

In checking the return, it is found that several of the register numbers have been changed, as follows:

| September Quarter Return | December Quarter Return |
|--------------------------|-------------------------|
| No. 137 Donald Moody     | Percy Gonzales          |
| " 138 Henry Charlie      | Thomas Williams         |
| " 139 Percy Gonzales     | Leonard Baker           |
| " 140 Thomas Williams    | Gilbert Band            |

The name of Henry Charlie is not shown on the December quarter return although no application has been received for his discharge.

Donald Moody was shown on the September quarter return as No. 137 and on the December quarter return as No. 127, which was his register number when he was formerly in the school during the September quarter, 1930. No. 127 should be retained by this boy during his period of residence.

Please let me have full information regarding the above and you should point out to the Reverend Principal that the register number given a pupil on admission should be retained during the whole period of residence. Accordingly, on future returns, Percy Gonzales should be shown as No. 139; Thomas Williams as No. 140; Leonard Baker as No. 141; Gilbert Band as No. 142; and Herbert Band as No. 143.

For your convenience, a duplicate copy of this letter is enclosed, which you can hand to the Reverend Principal.

You may also inform the Principal that the admission of Herbert Baker, Molly Charlie and John Baker is approved.

Your obedient servant,

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,

Dear Sir:

As I wrote the School Report for December Quarter, I am charged by the Principal to correct the errors found in it:

(a) No. 118, Edward Corkill is now attending the Squamish Day School and very likely, the Principal forgot to notify the Department of the fact, but she will do so directly, giving reasons.

(b) As I knew that Donald Hoody retained his former No. 127, after the expiration of sick leave, I entered Percy Gonzales under No. 137.

(c) Henry Charlie's name was entered in the Statement for admission, last September, but was rejected by the Indian Agent, Mr. Ball, who said he would settle this matter with Ottawa. As his name never appeared on the school register, I gave No. 134 to Thomas Williams and followed the order for the two next boys: Leonard Baker and Gilbert Band.

I meant to inform you of the change but overlooked doing so. But to comply with the directions given in your letter of January 12, Thomas Williams shall henceforth appear under No. 140, Leonard Baker No. 141, Gilbert Band No. 142, and Herbert Baker No. 143.

I am sorry to say that No. 139, Percy Gonzales died in St. Paul's hospital, on December 28.

Sincerely regretting the trouble I unintentionally caused you, I am, dear Sir,

Respectfully yours,

Sister Mary Alex.
Ottawa, February 1st, 1932.

Madam,

Ottawa, April 23rd, 1932.

Madam,

It has been brought to the Department's attention that, in preparing the March quarter return of the Squamish Indian Residential School, per capita allowance is requested for ninety-one (91) days for pupils 0121 and 0122, whereas both of these girls were out of school for at least two months. In this connection, I would point out that extreme care should be exercised in preparing the quarterly return.

Under the heading "Total number of days pupil in residence during quarter", there should be entered only the actual number of days each pupil is in residence during the quarter which the return covers. If a pupil is absent owing to illness or any other cause, per capita allowance should not be requested for the period of absence. For instance, if a pupil is absent for thirty (30) days, the figure 62 should appear under this heading opposite such pupil's name and, in the column headed "Remarks", etc., the reason for absence should be stated.

I also enclose for your guidance a copy of circular letter of October 19th, 1923.

Your obedient servant,

July 21, 1933.

Dear Sir:

As you were told on your short visit of the 19th inst., Mother Amy will be taken up the whole week by her instructions to, and conferences with, her staff and the Sisters from the other schools, and she can dispose of very little time outside of these. Therefore I answer your letter of the 19th regarding the re-admission of No.123, Louis George, to school.

I looked up all the papers for information concerning this matter. All I could find is that, accompanying the return for the December Quarter, a sick leave was asked for him.

As far as I know, a child who has been left at home on a sick leave can come back to school and be re-entered on the register without any notification to the Department. This boy came back after two and a half months of absence, that is, some time in March.

Kindly let the Principal know if any further adjustment is necessary.

I am, dear Sir,

Respectfully yours,

(Sgd.) Sister Mary Alix.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant regarding the June quarter return of the Squamish Indian Residential School.

There appears to be a misunderstanding on the part of the Principal, and her assistant, Sister Mary Alix, has written to say that the discharge of 123 L. George was not asked for in the December quarter.

The return for that quarter shows this pupil "suffering from rheumatism, is on sick leave". The Principal was therefore in error in showing the pupil as discharged. He returned to School in March and not having been considered by the Principal as discharged, she did not think it necessary to apply for his re-admission.

A copy of the Sister's letter is enclosed herewith.

I have the honour to be,

Ottawa, October 9th, 1936.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, with reference to certain applications for the admission of children to the Squamish Indian Residential School.

In view of your statement that Stanley Joseph, Andrew Paul and Ed. Nahanees are in a position to support their children, the Department is not prepared to approve their admission to the Squamish Indian Residential School. They should continue to attend the day school and reside at home.

Regarding the applications for Rodney and Margaret Nahanees, and Jacob and Madeleine Louie, please let me know if William Nahanees and Lewis Louie admit that they are the fathers of these children. If you have definite admission to this effect, the Department is prepared to consider withholding any interest money due these two Indians and fund same for the support of the children. You should, also, state with whom the children are living at the present time and whether or not they are receiving proper care and attention.

The application form signed by Moses Guss for the admission of Marjorie Thomas states that Guss is only her guardian. Please let me know for what length of time this girl has been in Guss' care and whether or not he has children of his own to support. If so, it is possible that it would be in the girl's best interests to place her in a residential school.

If more pupils are required at the Squamish Residential School to bring the enrolment to the number for which grant is allowed, the Department considers that you should assist the Principal in securing the necessary pupils. Preference, of course, should be given to orphan and neglected children.

You may inform the Principal that the admission of Mary Madeleine George and Clare Thomas is approved.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

re: File No. 167-1-10.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant regarding admissions into Squamish Residential School, and with reference to the last paragraph thereof would say that I have secured more than enough pupils to fill their quota. This morning's attendance was 62, and two or three truants will return before the end of the month. The grant is for 60 only, but they usually have from 60 to 65 pupils in attendance.

I have notified the School in accordance with your letter that you have approved five admissions, but have not approved admission of Stanley Joseph, W. Joseph, Jimmie Nahanee, and Y. Paul. They have been in residence since August, and the Principal is reluctant to let them go, as they are above the average in intelligence, etc.

Please note that in your letter of the 9th instant you approved the admission of Mary George, see last paragraph, so presumably you included her name among those not approved in error.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:

I beg to report that six boys left the Squamish Residential School at 7 p.m. on the 1st instant. One returned within a few hours but claimed he did not know where the others went.

There was a depth of several inches of snow on the ground and the weather was fairly cold for this part of the Province.

All avenues were watched, even the look-out at the entrance to the harbour, as they had said something about going to Squamish by canoe.

All five were found next day several miles from the School, having spent the night with a white man who is married to an Indian woman. They were returned to School apparently none the worse for their experience.

I am reporting this because it may reach you indirectly and through alarmist channels. There was no reason for the truancy; they were merely tired of confinement in the School as we are not allowing the pupils to visit the Indian village on account of epidemics of measles and influenza.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]
Indian Agent.

REPORT FOR MONTH OF FEBRUARY 1937, ON VANCOUVER AGENCY.

On the 1st at 1.30 P.M. I received a telephone call from Squamish Indian Residential School that six boys had been missing from the school since 7 P.M. the previous evening. Immediate search was made and the boys were found next day at Lynn Valley, and all well though wet and tired on account of the deep snow. I instructed the school authorities again that it is vitally necessary to notify this office immediately a pupil is missing. We might easily have had a repetition of the Lejac tragedy. I think the Residential schools should be especially instructed by the Department in this matter.

F. J. C. Ball;
Indian Agent.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo re the Squamish Residential School report including Stanley and Willard Joseph.

I regret having overlooked writing you in explanation of the apparent contradiction in this matter. I considered that as the father was longing at fair wages, the pupils should be selected from those who were either orphans or in poor circumstances, and it was arranged that the two boys mentioned should be day pupils instead of residents, and this was explained to you in October, 1936.

Shortly afterwards, the mother suddenly decamped from the Reserve, and left the father to take care of several small children. We have not yet succeeded in getting the mother back home again, and we had to place the children in residence as no one was taking care of them.

I hope this explanation will cover the admission of these boys and that you will approve same under the altered circumstances.

1. On the 13-4-38 information was received that three Indian boys, Lorne Antone, Donald Moody and Sammy Louis had left the Indian Residential School at North Vancouver, B.C. Inquiries were made and it was learned that the missing boys were at Squamish, B.C.

2. On 18-4-38 Cst.Gill, of the B.C.P.Police stationed at Squamish, B.C. sent the above mentioned Indian boys back to Vancouver, B.C. Via Union Steamship, boat was met by Cst.J.F.Piper and writer, and the Indian boys were escorted to the Vancouver City Police Station where they were held until the following day, at which time they were escorted to the Juvenile Detention Home, Vancouver, B.C. Where they were held in custody for the B.C.P.Police, pending a charge of theft.

3. On the 23-4-38 the above named Indian boys appeared in the Lynn Valley, District court before R.A.Sargent, Police Magistrate, when evidence was heard they were found Guilty, and sentenced to be whipped, execution of same was carried out by Charlie Antone and Andrew Louis, fathers of the accused boys, and Indian boys were handed over in the custody of parents.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR MONTH OF APRIL - VANCOUVER AGENCY.

Three schoolboys from Squamish Indian Residential school who ran away last month and were given school tasks as punishment, again ran away on the 14th. They had no excuse or complaint against the school, and two of them would be leaving next term on reaching the age limit. As they had broken into some houses and stolen considerable property, they were brought up in Juvenile Court, and given a whipping by their parents by order of the Court. This seems to be a satisfactory arrangement, but the school refuses to take the boys back on account of the possible bad influence on the remaining pupils.

Sir:

In connection with the enclosed voucher for $3.75 in favour of the B.C.Provincial Police, I beg to advise that this represents the balance of the cost of apprehending the three Indian boys who ran away from Squamish Indian Residential School last month. The Police located the boys at Squamish and the total cost of getting them back to Vancouver amounted to $13.55 (as shown on the account attached to the voucher), but I was able to collect $9.80 from the boys' shares of the recent Squamish interest distribution. The boys involved were Lorne Antone, No.5; Donald Moody, No.67; and Sammy Louie, No.84, all of the Squamish Band.

The boys obtained sufficient money to take them to Squamish by stealing some baskets from an Indian house on Squamish I.R.No.1, and selling them in Vancouver to a Japanese store. It was necessary to reimburse the store for the $10.00 they paid the boys, and the baskets were restored to their owner. While awaiting trial for this theft, they were held at the Juvenile Detention Home for 4 days each at $0.20 per day, making a total cost of $10.20, which also had to be paid.

Their shares of interest money ($10.00 per capita) were applied to the above expenses as follows:

|--------------------------------------------------|--------|
| Cheque                                           |        |

| Total                                            | $33.75 |

Less 3 shares @ $10.00 each......................| $30.00 |

Balance as per voucher herewith...................| $3.75 |

The boys received suspended sentence on condition that their parents whipped them, which was done. As they would have been discharged at the end of June in any case having reached the age of 16, and the Principal did not want them back in the School again on account of bad influence, (this being their second offence within a month) they have not returned to School.

On the 30th, I was called to Squamish Residential school as four boys including the two found at Musqueam, had left school during the night. I phoned the Provincial Police in West Vancouver to be on the look-out and the boys were located on Capilano Reserve and returned to school. Constable Durnin, R.C.M.P. and I went to the school and found the boys had been duly punished before we arrived. SIR:-

With reference to the September Quarter Report of the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, it has been discovered that Pupils No. 0709, Renee Miranda, No.0710, Myrna Miranda and No.0711, Benita Miranda of the Squamish Band, Vancouver Agency, are Catholics, and they have accordingly been transferred to the Squamish Mission Indian Residential School at North Vancouver.

I have been informed by the Vancouver Office that no applications for admission for these children have gone through, so I have requested that they be rendered to you now from the Squamish Mission Indian Residential School.

There appears to have been some misunderstanding in connection with the admission of these children between the Vancouver Agency, and the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, but as soon as the circumstances were discovered, the Reverend Mr. Scott brought the children down to Vancouver, and turned them back to the Vancouver Office, so the fault does not lie at his door.

Your obedient servant,

A.O.N. Daunt.
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to advise that the Sister Superior of Squamish Indian Residential School requests the immediate discharge of No. 0185, Mildred Baker, who is unmanageable, swears at the Sisters, runs away from school, and generally sets a bad example. She was found with a soldier in Vancouver on one occasion, and figured in a juvenile delinquency case.

Mildred Baker was born January 28th 1926, and is, therefore, in her 15th year. She is the daughter of No. 9, William Baker, Jr., of the Squamish Band. Both William Baker Jr., and his wife, Caroline, are worthless Indians, and Caroline is continually in jail - in fact, is there now. They have a large family, who are left to themselves without any parental control, so it is not surprising to find the children difficult to handle.

If we discharge this girl, she will immediately follow in her parents' footsteps and become a prostitute in Vancouver.

I would recommend that she be placed in the care of the Convent of the Good Shepherd in Vancouver, where she may, under different surroundings, improve in character. The Convent will accept her at $15.00 a month, which is little more than we are paying the Squamish Residential School, and I respectfully request your authority to place her there forthwith.

She could be committed to the Provincial Girls' Industrial School, but she will be worse rather than better when she is released, and the authorities there are reluctant to accept a young Indian girl unless committed to them by the Juvenile Court.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.G.Ball]
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Dear Sir:

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa:

On Saturday, the 23rd instant, 9 girls left Squamish Indian Residential School at 9 a.m. without permission. At 10 a.m. the Sister Superior notified me of their absence and search was started. No trace of any kind could be found, but late on Saturday night a telephone message was received that they had called at the home of an Indian woman on Lulu Island and except for her two girls, had left for St. Mungo's Cannery near New Westminster. They were finally located and brought back to School late Sunday night, except the two who returned today. They were all warmly dressed and have apparently suffered no ill-effects.

I have investigated the cause for this truancy but it was apparently only a prank, and evidently arranged the evening before they left.

I am reporting this only as a matter of record or in case news of their absence had been received by you, as I understand the radio was used to help find them. They ranged in age from 8 to 14 years and were led by the two oldest girls of the party. These latter two are a bad influence at the school and have run away four or five times before.

Indian Agent.

B/DH.
On the 23rd, during the cold spell, 8 girls ranging in age from 8 to 14, left the Squamish Residential School without leave at 9 a.m. Naturally it was expected they would go only as far as the village, but no trace of them could be found. On account of the weather, some uneasiness was felt until an Indian woman living on Lulu Island near New Westminster telephoned to say that they had all arrived at her place late at night. They were returned to school on Sunday and Monday. They had no complaint and apparently did it for a prank.

Fred J.C. Ball,
Indian Agent.

F.J.C. Ball, Indian Agent,

Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Mr. Ball,

I am sending to your office the Quarterly Reports for the Squamish Residential and Day Schools.

You will notice that the average attendance at the Residential school is lower than previously. This is due to the reduced pupilage (now numbering 61 instead of 65) and the number of children who had to be sent to the hospital.

I hope though that the Department will kindly overlook the average, considering that, in spite of the per capita grant reduction since the war started, we kept the same number of children in residence as before. And, as you are aware, Sir, the school now pays the taxes on the land it occupies, which Ottawa did before. A new curtailment of the grant would greatly handicap the school management.

Would you kindly bring this special affair concerning the school before the Department?

I am, dear Mr. Ball,

Respectfully yours,

Sister Mary Alix.

re: File No. 167-1-10

The other girl, Elsie Gonzales, has just figured in a disgusting Court case in North Vancouver. The girl's father, Arthur Gonzales, made a great disturbance when his daughter was missing from school, and advised the Sisters that he was spending day and night looking for her, and we had much sympathy for him. Elsie was returned to his custody, but three weeks later, to our amazement, the Police notified me that the girl, accompanied by her married sister and a young brother, had called upon them and laid a charge of incest against the father. The case came up for trial and after three sessions at Court, he was convicted this morning and given 18 months imprisonment. The evidence given was most revolting and incriminated him in connection with all three of his daughters. Personally I think the sentence was much too light but, of course, we have no control over that.

There is no place to which we can send this girl as Lejac School does not want her, and I believe that if we could now release Mildred Baker from the Good Shepherd Home and Send Elsie Gonzales there in her place, it will be the best place for her and everyone else.

Will you kindly authorize this to be done.

Fred. J.C. Ball.
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, April 23rd, 1946.

J. D. Caldwell, Acting Agent,
416 Federal Bldg., Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to the March Quarterly Return, the Squamish Indian Residential School, it is requested that you draw the Principal's attention to the following discrepancies:

1) The March Quarter consisted only of 90 days, and not 92 days as shown on your return. 2) Circular letter #150-87 of December 1944, states that a pupil may draw grant up until 30 days while in hospital. 3) When showing the number of days in the column under the heading "days in residence" ditto marks should not be used.

It is also noted that pupil #0209 has been in hospital for three quarters, and if this girl is not expected to return to the school, her discharge should be applied for.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, January 22, 1947.

Mr. H.E. Taylor, Indian Agent, 416 Federal Building,
Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to the Squamish December Quarterly Return, it is requested that you bring the following discrepancies to the attention of the Principal:

1. The Return shows pupils who were in hospital for less than thirty days deducted for the number of days they were in hospital. This is incorrect for grant is allowed for pupils up to thirty days hospitalization in any one Quarter.

2. Ditto marks cause confusion and it is requested that in the column headed "Attendance" that figures be shown or the number of days pupils are in residence.

3. Pupil No. 0209 Laverne Leon was not shown on the September Quarterly Return but ninety-two days was requested on the December Return. Please advise the date the pupil returned to school.

4. Pupil No. 0215 Marion Billy entered hospital on November 21st and fifty-three days grant was requested. With reference to paragraph one this pupil is allowed thirty days hospital grant and is therefore entitled to eighty-two days.
The above corrections have been made on the December Quarterly Return and are only brought to your attention for the purpose of speeding up the checking of future returns and thus ensuring prompt forwarding of the school grant cheque.

Phil'p Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Re: Squamish Residential School.

The Vancouver Agency is having considerable difficulty in finding Residential School accommodation for necessitous cases. This is due to the fact that some children whose home circumstances are good are now enrolled at the Squamish and the Sechelt Residential Schools. It is therefore felt that nine children from the Squamish Reserves should be discharged to make room for these necessitous cases. Children discharged in this manner can attend the provincial schools at Squamish. It is therefore requested that authority be granted for the discharge of the following children:

CIRCULAR - TO ALL SUPERINTENDENTS AND PRINCIPALS OF RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This office is concerned that the best possible use does not appear to be made of the Residential Schools. It is believed that many children who should be in Residential Schools are being prevented from being admitted by the presence of children in Residential Schools who could very well attend Day Schools.

It has always been the Department's policy to have Superintendents approve the admission of children to Residential Schools and have them indicate their approval by signing the application forms for pupils entering Residential School. No child should be admitted to a Residential School unless these forms have been completed. It is the responsibility of a Superintendent in whose Agency the Residential School is located to check the quarterly return with the application forms and delete pupils from the quarterly return for whom there is no completed application form. Application forms from outside Agencies should be forwarded to the Superintendent in charge of the Agency in which the Residential School is located for forwarding to the Department. The practice of having children admitted to Residential Schools without the approval of the Superintendent should not be tolerated. Such practice, in addition to permitting accommodation to be used by children who have no need for this type of service, is a contributing factor to the lengthy delay which often occurs in making family allowance returns and the resulting over-payment of allowances.

As a guide to Superintendents, the following order of precedence is given:

1. Children whose home circumstances require that they be given institutional care.
2. Children from Reserves where there is no Day School or inadequate facilities.
3. Children who have reached high school level.

Re: Squamish Residential School

Further to my letter of September 11th, Miss Grant has completed a partial investigation and the home and other circumstances of some of the Squamish Band pupils enrolled in the Squamish Residential School are detailed in her report attached.

In the absence of Supt. Taylor these families have been discussed with Mr. Henson and it is agreed that there is no apparent reason why all of the children listed who are enrolled in the residential school should not live at home and attend on a day basis.

It is intended at an early date to review the circumstances of the other pupils enrolled in the school but in the meantime I would recommend that the Frank Guerrero children, the Chief Moses Joseph children, the William Billy children and the Dominic Baker children be discharged from the residential school and required to attend on a day basis.

It is understood that the enrolment approved and pending at the above mentioned school will total approximately 85 pupils whereas the authorized enrolment is only 70. The Reverend Principal is reluctant to refuse the applications pending for the reason that the pupils' home conditions in all cases are alleged to be such that admission to a residential school is essential.

Under the circumstances we have arranged to have Miss Grant review the circumstances with regard to every one of the 85 pupils who if required to live at home would have educational facilities available.

Sir:

For some time I have been thinking of communicating with you concerning the establishment of at least two Manual Training Centres, in connection with our Indian Schools.

You are aware that for four years Rev. G.H. Naley has been carrying on a manual training program at Coqualeetza Residential School.

The Manual Training Instructor, Mr. A.G. Jamieson, is well qualified to carry on this work. He has charge of the Manual Training Work in connection with the Public Schools of the Chilliwack Valley.

Two nights of each week from seven P.M. to nine P.M., he instructs ten of the Indian boys systematically and scientifically.

I would respectfully recommend to the Department that two Manual training centres be opened this autumn in connection with our Indian Schools. First, in connection with the Squamish Residential School; second, in connection with the Nanaimo Bay School.
I would further recommend that these two centres be equipped with ten benches each and whatever tools are necessary to successfully carry on this work.

At both of these centres it will be possible to have the services of two efficient instructors. My idea is that we should employ men who are making a success of their work in the Public Schools. We must have men of good standing to introduce this work.

These schools would be carried on along the same line as the Night Schools. This work would have to be conducted in this way as the men that we would engage would be able to come to us only at night. In the daytime they would be at work in connection with the public schools.

Mr. Raley pays the instructor in his school $4.00 for each night, so that the expense in connection with the two centres that I have suggested. At this rate it would cost $16.00 per week for the time the school is carried on.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Schools.

Sir,

I have the honour to report that the Department's letter of September and ultimo, No.167-1-1, addressed to Mr. R.H. Cairns Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia and having reference to the establishment of a Manual Training Centre at the Squamish Indian School, North Vancouver, was duly handed to me by Mr. Cairns for perusal.

Previously to this letter having been received by Mr. Cairns, the Inspector, and I had visited the Strathcona Public School Manual Training Centre together and had made some notes in this connection. Subsequently, to the receipt of this letter, Mr. Cairns & I visited the Provincial Public School at North Vancouver and there made survey of the Manual Training Centre. We met Mr. F. Wilcox, City School Manual Training Instructor, with whom we discussed various phases of Manual Training Work. We told Mr. Wilcox that we were gleaning data as a basis of a recommendation to the Department respecting a proposed Manual Training Centre for the Squamish Indian Residential School, whereupon he placed himself at our disposal and assisted us in every way possible in pursuit of our investigation. Mr. Wilcox accompanied us on our visit to the Squamish Indian Residential School for the purpose of looking over whatever accommodation might be available there for Manual Training purposes. We further consulted with the School Staff and after careful survey of prevailing conditions we came to the conclusion that the space available was utterly inadequate and unsuitable for the purpose. It was apparent that if a Manual Training Centre were to be established in connection with the school a cheap and suitable building would have to be erected to accommodate the equipment and serve the pupilage. It was decided, upon mutual discussion, to recommend that the Department make a grant for the construction of a suitable building and I proceeded at once to investigate details of the probable cost of a building, equipment, etc. Fortunately, I was able to secure the assistance of Mr. R.F. Wheaton (the contractor who erected the fire escapes at this school last year), and he very kindly prepared a sketch plan showing the local requirements together with a list of quantities in regard to material etc., required for the construction of an inexpensive.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
of an inexpensive and fairly substantial wooden frame building.

After making careful inquiries, assisted by Mr. Inspector Cairns, Mr. Wheadon and Mr. Wilcox, an estimate of the approximate cost of installing a Manual Training Building and equipment such as would meet the requirements of the above mentioned school, is as follows:

1. Building including all labour & material $950.00
2. 10 benches @ $17.50 ........................................... $175.00
3. Cupboards, sawboard, tool racks, side benches approximately .................................................. $40.00
4. Instructor, 80 lessons at $5 ........................................ $400.00
5. Tools, approximately ................................................ $50.00
6. Drawing materials .................................................... $10.00
7. Hardware, glue and paint ........................................... $15.00
8. Lumber for Manual Training work ................................ $75.00

Total $1465.00

Of the foregoing total the sum of $1465.00 represents the initial outlay in installing the plant and the remaining $950.00 represents the estimated and approximate annual expenditure based upon eighty lessons per year at $5.00 per lesson. It has been thought best to recommend the appointment of an instructor at $5.00 per lesson rather than on stated salary so as to provide for possible broken periods or cessation of work.

The plan of the proposed building and equipment is submitted herewith, together with a bill of quantities connected with the building and a list of tools necessary for the carrying on of this work. These will be self-explanatory, and with regard to the tools and manual training lumber it is not expected that these would all be purchased at once but it was deemed advisable to give the Department an approximate total cost of the tools and material required.

Mr. Inspector Cairns and I have today gone over the specifications etc., and we have decided to submit the data thus gathered to the Department with a recommendation that authority be granted to proceed with this installation at the earliest possible date. We feel that we have cut down the cost as closely as can be done commensurately with the local requirements.

As to a Training Instructor, Mr. Cairns and I have agreed to ask the Department to appoint Mr. Wilcox as Instructor under the terms mentioned above, as we believe he is a thoroughly capable man and he is at present engaged in the Public School Manual Training Centre as Instructor and is giving satisfaction there. We believe Mr. Wilcox who has obliged us in every possible way in making our investigations would fully meet our requirements in connection with this school.
I would inform the Department that whilst visiting the Squamish Residential School the Rev. Principal, Mother Mary Amy expressed a wish to have an additional classroom built over the proposed Manual Training Building, but Mr. Carling and I regret not being able to recommend this in connection with the proposed building, as the substructure to take care of an additional classroom overhead would have to be more substantial and would consequently be more costly and would involve the preparation of plans and specifications on a larger scale.

I would further call attention of the Department to the fact that the Squamish Indian Residential School Building is showing considerable all-round decay in the foundations of the building, which indicates that it is only a matter of time and it will become necessary to dispense with the old building.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir,

With further reference to Departmental letter dated June 8th, No. 1627, in connection with a resolution of the Squamish Indian Council, with respect to the proposed erection of a combined Manual Training Hall, Gymnasium and Auditorium for the use of the Indians of the Reserve and the pupils of the Squamish Residential school, I have the honour to transmit herewith a tentative sketch plan giving the various aspects of the proposed building, for the further guidance of the Department.

Accompanying this sketch will be found two statements, the first representing figures obtained from three Vancouver builders, who have estimated the cost of the proposed building upon the bases of the sketch submitted at $7294.00, $6105.00 and $6790, respectively; the second statement indicating the prospective cost of furnishing and equipping the proposed building for the purpose of manual training. I have not figured on the cost of gymnasium equipment, as it has not yet been decided what equipment will be required in that connection.

I regret there has been some delay in procuring this information, but the Department will be aware that it is difficult to secure prices from contractors unless it is an estimate based upon work which they have some prospect of obtaining; hence I have been obliged to feel my way along and secure the information as best I could, not having received any authority from the Department to incur expenditure in this connection.

I trust that the information thus furnished will give the Department and its architect a better idea of what is wanted. It is proposed to heat the building with a furnace but to build a chimney and have a stove on each floor, sufficient for the purpose of heating the rooms. It is proposed to shiplap the exterior walls of the building up to the second floor, and from there to the roof it is suggested that it be shingled and stained. It is proposed also to plaster the rooms on the ground floor and to joint the Manual Training room upstairs. It is proposed to construct a septic tank, ten feet square.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

When Andrew Faull, of the Squamish Band, was in Ottawa some months ago, he was very keen on a community building for the reserve - one that could be used as an auditorium and a gymnasium and which could be equipped with manual training facilities for the special use of the older pupils of the Squamish Indian Residential School. I suggested that the interested members of the Band have the Indian Council pass on an expenditure from their funds for the purpose. I advised against the erection of such a building on the school property and suggested that it be on the nearest point on the reserve which is close at hand.

Some time ago, a resolution of the Band in Council in this connection came to hand, and I asked Mr. Indian Agent Perry to prepare a rough sketch and secure estimates of the cost. These are now on file and I wish to recommend that the Department Architect prepare a plan of a suitable building and estimate its cost. Such a plan could be returned to the Council for their consideration, with a request for a further resolution indicating the exact amount required for not only the erection of the building but for the equipment necessary. Mr. Inspector Cairns and Mr. Indian Agent Perry both endorse the scheme.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT,

With reference to the attached letter from Dr. King, I wish to report that it is now timely to make arrangements for a manual training instructor, who will give classes in the evening to the young men of the Squamish Indian Reserve. He should also give one half day's instruction per week in the daytime for pupils of the Squamish Indian Residential School, in all a total of 3 lessons per week, two in the evening and one in the daytime. As soon as an instructor is selected, it will be necessary for him to indicate just what equipment and materials are required for our purposes. The classes will be held in the new community hall and manual training centre, which has recently been opened on the Reserve.

I understand that funds could be found in the Band's Interest Account to pay for this activity; but I am of the opinion that it would be a proper charge against the special appropriation of $100,000 per annum for British Columbia Indian work. It has already been proposed that $20,000 of this special appropriation be used for vocational training.

Previous to the receipt of Dr. King's recommendation that Mr. E. F. Hopkinson, of 156 Seventh Ave. W., Vancouver, be employed, Messrs. Cairns and Perry suggested that Mr. Wilcox, manual training instructor for North Vancouver City Schools, be given the work. I may say there has been no correspondence of late regarding the commencement of the activity.

I recommend that Mr. Hopkinson be advised to apply to Mr. Indian Agent Perry for the work and that our representative be instructed to make a report, not only on the instructor to be engaged, but on the activity generally.

Russell T. Ferrier

Ipswich,
March 29th 1912.

It is with the utmost possible pleasure that I comply with the request to give Mr. & Mrs. R. H. Shockley a testimonial as to their splendid ability as Superintendent and Matron of our St. John's Home for Children in this town.

I have had 24 years' experience as a Poor Law Guardian in Ipswich, and have always been on the St. John's Home Committee, so have been able to judge of the fitness of the various Officials we have had from time to time, and I can truthfully say that we have never had a better couple as Superintendent and Matron than Mr. & Mrs. Shockley and that is saying a great deal, for we have had some good occupants of the posts previous to their coming here. Mr. Shockley has proved himself to be a very capable administrator, also a good disciplinarian, and has carried out all his duties in a manner entirely to the satisfaction of the Guardians. He has kept a large set of books accurately; he has carried out many improvements in the Home, and obtained for the Guardians a large increase in the grant of money for Industrial Training.

Mrs. Shockley has not only been a first class Matron, conscientiously and carefully carrying out her duties to the entire satisfaction of the Guardians, but she has been like a Mother to the children of our Home; and it will be a terrible wrench to all when she leaves us.

I am sure it will be a very difficult thing to fill their places with a similar couple of capable, energetic, and willing officers. I sincerely wish them great success in their future career, and can confidently recommend them to any body who requires such competent officers as Mr. & Mrs. Shockley have proved themselves to be.

(Signed) W. H. CALVER,
Chairman of the Ipswich Board of Guardians.
Mr. and Mrs. R. H. Shockley entered the service of these Institutions in June, 1903, as Superintendent and Matron of Branch Home for Little Boys at Leopold House, Burdett Road, E., where over 300 boys are in residence.

In 1904 a vacancy occurred at the Headquarters, 18 to 26, Stepney Causeway, where the responsibilities were greater and where boys of a more advanced age were in residence, and Mr. and Mrs. Shockley were invited by the late Dr. Barnardo to fill this post, and they were in possession when I took up the duties of Director in October, 1905.

I have much pleasure in stating that Mr. and Mrs. Shockley carried through the responsibilities entrusted to them in a very satisfactory manner. We considered them to be good managers and organisers, and they had the welfare of the boys at heart.

Mr. Shockley also took a great interest in the boys' sports, and did much to foster a spirit of friendly rivalry between the different dormitories.

It was with regret that I received Mr. and Mrs. Shockley's resignation in August last on their securing a joint appointment under the Local Government Board.

(Signed)

WM. BAKER, M.A., L.L.B.,
Honorary Director and Chairman of Council.
Mossford Lodge, Barking Side,
Ilford, Essex.

June 29th, 1908.

Dear Mr. Shockley,

You have asked me to do a very hard task—yet I know Dr. Barnardo would do it, for he never stood in the way of any of his beloved co-workers' advancement, and especially if they had their own children to think of.

I know how he valued you and Mrs. Shockley whilst at Leopold House, and how wise, kind, and tactful he thought you—not only in your dealings with the boys, but also with your staff—and he regretted moving you both to Stepney, but he felt that needed the best Superintendent he could get.

How faithfully you and Mrs. Shockley have worked, and how hard it has been for you! To me your leaving is a personal sorrow, for the Institutions can ill spare the devotion and unselfish service of those who were chosen by and known by their Founder.

With kind wishes to you both, believe me,

Always your sincere friend,

(Signed) SYRIE LOUISE BARNARDO.

2, Amen Court, St. Paul's,
London, E.C.

May, 1903.

Mr. R. H. Shockley informs me he is a candidate for the position of Superintendent of a Boys' Home under your control, and he asks me for a testimonial in support of his candidature, which I give with pleasure.

Mr. Shockley has been Head Schoolmaster in our Certified Industrial School here for over two years, during which period he has well and faithfully discharged the duties appertaining to that position.

Further, I am pleased to know that he has applied himself not only to the training and education of the lads as far as their school-room work was concerned, but has interested himself in the well-being and happiness of those under his charge, beyond the lines required of him at his engagement. Being a good athlete he has taken an active part in the boys' cricket, football, games, etc., as well as helping in their physical training, and being a good Tonic-Sol-Fa trainer, he has rendered valuable work in the teaching of singing. He has taught our Evening Science Classes under the Board of Education, and also Manual Training in Woodwork.

He is steady, regular and attentive. Since he came here he has taken up Institutional work with a view to obtain such a position as that he is now seeking. In fact, when he applied for our vacant position of Schoolmaster, he told me that was his object in undertaking duty in an Industrial School.

Possibly you may be aware that Macclesfield Industrial School is noted for its industrial training, and doubtless the experience and knowledge gained here by Mr. Shockley will be most helpful to him should he be successful in his present application.

I firmly believe he would prove himself a faithful and efficient officer.

He has my best wishes, and I shall be pleased to answer any questions concerning him.

(Signed) P. J. EATON, J.P.,

Dear Sir,

In accordance with your recent request, I have the honor to report on the application of Mr. E.F. Hopkinson for the position of Manual Training Instructor for the Squamish Indian Reserve manual training school which is attached to the Squamish Indian Residential School, North Vancouver.

There has been a little delay in this matter owing to the absence from home of Mr. R.H. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia. We have interviewed Mr. Hopkinson and we requested him to present testimonials as to his fitness for the position. These have been received and copies of the same are sent herewith for your perusal.

Mr. Inspector Cairns and I have interviewed both these applicants, and now recommend the appointment of Mr. R.H. Shockley on probation for a period of six months, the appointment to continue upon assurance being given the Department as to his services. Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT.

With reference to the attached letter from Dr. King, I wish to report that it is now timely to make arrangements for a manual training instructor, who will give classes in the evening to the young men of the Squamish Indian Reserve. He should also give one half day's instruction per week in the daytime for pupils of the Squamish Indian Residential School - in all a total of 3 lessons per week, two in the evening and one in the daytime. As soon as an instructor is selected, it will be necessary for him to indicate just what equipment and materials are required for our purposes. The classes will be held in the new community hall and manual training centre, which has recently been opened on the Reserve.

I understand that funds could be found in the Band's Interest Account to pay for this activity; but I am of the opinion that it would be a proper charge against the special appropriation of $100,000 per annum for British Columbia Indian work. It has already been proposed that $20,000 of this special appropriation be used for vocational training.

Previous to the receipt of Dr. King's recommendation that Mr. E. P. Hopkinson, of 156 Seventh Ave., W., Vancouver, be employed, Messrs. Cairns and Perry suggested that Mr. Wilcox, manual training instructor for North Vancouver City Schools, be given the work. Dear Mr. Mitchburn:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to manual training at the Indian schools of British Columbia. I am very desirous of getting this activity extended without delay, and, as a preliminary step, I have to authorize you to purchase the materials listed on the enclosure you forwarded. The materials for work benches, the individual and general sets of tools and the drawing sets indicated should be supplied to the Kamloops, Squamish, Luper Island, Cariboo, St. Mary's, St. George's, Alert Bay and Fraser Lake schools. As the Squamish activity can be started immediately, work benches, Osmond's, may be purchased. For Squamish, you may supply $650 worth of equipment, as listed in your letter. The Department is already in correspondence with the Reverend Mr. Scott, concerning suitable workshops for St. George's. I rely upon you to purchase to the best advantage and to write to the principals concerned, explaining the use to which this equipment will be put. You may also authorize each principal to purchase lumber with which to work, as soon as the classes can be started. You may fix the amount to be expended on these materials from $50 to $100, as indicated in your letter, and you should direct principals to make requisition to the Indian agent for further materials, when required. If you find that any expenditure is necessary to complete the carpenter shop at Fraser Lake, you should let the Department have an estimate.

I have written a special letter to Father Rohr, of the Cariboo School, pointing out that the boys must not be overworked in connection with the supply of fuel, and I am satisfied that vocational training can be started at this institution also. The populace is being increased to assist with current financing, and I have clearly indicated that the extra grant is for the engaging of labour for the supply of fuel.

EXTRACT from Report of G. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for B. C., dated May 21st and 22nd, 1931, on his inspection of the SQUAMISH INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

Original on File 167-1-6.

Manual Training:

The Manual Training Shop is about 50 ft. by 40 ft. It contains 16 double benches. Sixteen boys are taking this training. They are divided into two classes. I saw these two classes at work. They seem to enjoy this subject. The teacher in charge of the work is Mr. Shockley of Vancouver. He is a member of the Vancouver Manual Training Staff and previously was for seven years at Prince Rupert. The boys draw plans of their work. The tools are well cared for. The course followed is that of the B. C. Schools as adapted by Vancouver.
