Dear Sir;

Following a conversation with respect to the Manual Training at the Squamish Indian Residential School which we had a couple of weeks ago, I visited the school on the 16th of November, and later in the day had an interview with the Manual Training Instructor which lasted nearly two hours. This last took place at the Devonshire Hotel, Vancouver.

The Manual Training Instructor is Mr. R.H. Shockley, a member of the Church of England, and about 55 years of age. He was a teacher in England, a Superintendent of the Barnardo's Home at Stepney and was later on the Manual Training staff in Prince Rupert. Mr. Shockley holds a Manual Training Certificate for the Province of British Columbia, obtained as a result of a short course here. He is not, as was previously reported in error a member of the Vancouver Manual Training staff; but he has been trying to follow the course adopted by the Vancouver City Schools.

Mr. Shockley, who appeared to be anxious that the work done at the Squamish Indian Residential School should be a success, stated that there were supposed to be two periods of two hours each on Friday afternoons between 1 P.M. and 5 P.M. The boys, twenty in all, are divided into two classes, the Junior of which is composed of boys in Grade 2 for the most part. Possibly the Senior Class gets a little more than the two hours, and the Junior Class a little less.

I am informed by Mr. Shockley that since the opening of school in September last the Seniors have made a spade, and a shelf which involved shaped ends, stopped lap joint, and stopped housing joint. The Juniors in the same period have been learning the use of the saw, chisel, and plane, on small pieces of wood. The work of the last school year was mainly small articles, as in the Vancouver City Schools. The largest article constructed appears to have been a small cabinet of about 24in. by 15 in. The boys take the articles away at the end of the year, on instructions issued through the late Indian Commissioner. I had therefore no opportunity to inspect the work. This is the fourth year that Mr. Shockley has been the Manual Training Instructor at this school.
I inspected the Manual Training Shop while I was in North Vancouver, and found everything tidy, the tools well cared for and neatly arranged, and no chips etc. on the floor. I observed the drawings done by the seniors - A SPOON. The classes were not working, nor was the Instructor present.

My opinion, arrived at after my talk with the teachers at the school and my interview with Mr. Shockley, is that very little if any worthwhile work has been done for some time, possibly since my last report on this school. I consider that the Instructor has been perfectly honest in his labours; but has been far too theoretical in his lectures etc. He has been following a course which very little can be urged, though it may be more suitable in Vancouver Schools. I have suggested to him that I shall inspect the work in detail early next Spring, and that in the mean time he should have the boys construct much larger and more useful articles, such as TABLES? CHAIRS, STOOLS, CUPBOARDS, LAMP STANDS, TOWEL HORSES, etc., involving the usual joints. I asked that Drawings should still be made; that they should not take too long to draw. I explained that what we wanted in Indian Schools was not so much EXTREM ACCURACY as a neat DIMENSION SKETCH. I further suggested that he should have the boys choose partners, and suggest the work they wished to do. I explained in detail just how he could make these changes in a natural manner with his classes, so that he would secure full cooperation of the pupils.

I am strongly of the opinion that Mr. Shockley should be given an opportunity to make good on this revised programme.

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry,
District Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. INSPECTOR BARRY ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE SQUAMISH INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL ON MARCH 23 and 24, 1933.

Manual Training:

That in view of the representations of the principal and senior teachers of the Squamish Indian Residential School with regard to the poor progress of pupils taking the manual training courses at the school, and the fact that it is impossible to report favourably on the work being done at the present time, I have no alternative but to request the Department to terminate the engagement of the present manual training instructor, Mr. A. H. Shockley, as from the end of June, 1933.

In making the above recommendation, I have taken the following facts into consideration:
There has been very little advance in the quality of the instruction given to these boys since my interview with Mr. Shockley last November.
The articles being constructed consist of stools, towel racks, salt boxes, brackets, and some small tables, and are not up to the required standard for this work in the Indian Schools.
The Director of manual training agrees with me that there are a number of well trained instructors available. I keep in very close touch with the above mentioned Director, Mr. J. Kyle, who tells suitable instructors to register their applications in this office.
Should the Department agree with me in the above, and decide to appoint a new manual training instructor at this school, there will be no difficulty in suggesting a very well trained and experienced person, properly qualified to each the subject to young Indian boys.

MR. C. C. PERRY, INDIAN COMMISSIONER FOR B.C.,
IN FORWARDING MR. INSPECTOR BARRY'S REPORT, COMMENTS AS FOLLOWS:

Manual Training Instruction:

Although it will be noted that this Instructor, Mr. Shockley, has a B.C. Manual Training Certificate - First Class in both woodwork and metal-work - and has also had a very long experience in both public and private schools, his present services are not satisfactory to Inspector Barry, nor are they satisfactory to Mr. Indian Agent Ball.

I understand that Mr. Kyle, Provincial Director of Manual Training in Public Schools, is anxious to have, wherever possible in our Indian schools as well as in his own schools, manual training instructors who are in the habit of keeping up to date by taking summer school courses under his direction. It seems to be quite possible that Mr. Shockley may be considered old-fashioned because he does not subscribe to these courses, and was not recommended by Mr. Kyle for appointment in the first instance. I am in agreement with Inspector Barry in that we should expect our instructors in manual training to keep reasonably efficient in their work; and if it is felt by the Indian Agent and the Inspector that a change is desirable in the interests of better work I would not place any obstruction in the way of such change.

Sir:

Tebb, the manual training instructor at the Sechelt Indian Residential School, be engaged to perform this work at the Squamish School also, the Department will agree to this arrangement. It is doubtful if he could give the necessary attention to the work for the two schools.

I shall be pleased if, after consulting the Inspector, you will forward the name, qualifications, etc., of the man whom you recommend for appointment at the Squamish Indian Residential School, to succeed Mr. Shockley.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant regarding a change of instructor in Manual Training at Squamish Indian Residential School and have advised Mr. Shockley that his services will not be required after the end of the present month.

I have just returned from Sechelt and consulted the Principal and Mr. Tebb. There is no doubt that Mr. Tebb's work has exceeded our expectations, and under his instruction the boys have done considerable repair work to the school, such as shingling and rebuilding sheds, etc., thus saving considerable money and giving the boys practical experience in work which they will be expected to do after they leave the school. In addition, Mr. Tebb, who is an experienced boat builder and has built a number of ships along the coast, is going to instruct the boys in boat building next term. This will be very valuable to the Coast Indians and more satisfactory probably than spending their time following the Provincial course of instruction.

Mr. Barry, Inspector of Schools, is not in favor of asking Mr. Tebb to take over the Squamish Indian School and he recommends Mr. Charles J. Merrick, 1248 Keith Road, Hollyburn, B.C., to replace Mr. Shockley. He states that Mr. Merrick is thirty-one years of age, married, holds a B.C. Manual Training Certificate and for the past four and a half years has been in charge of Manual Training in the District of North Vancouver and has been discharged recently on the plea of economy. Previously he was in charge of Manual Training at Ocean Falls for two years.

Mr. Merrick, in charge of this manual centre, is a gentleman of the highest character and exceptional capability. He is thorough and conscientious in his work, has a pleasing but firm class-room manner, and brings the knowledge of a varied experience and extensive training to his pupils. His work is well organized and systematic, and this is reflected in the able manner in which his pupils apply the practical work learned at manual to the more theoretical work of the class-room.

I may add that Mr. Merrick enjoys the esteem of the other members of this staff, his cheerfulness and willingness to help making him a valued asset to his school.

I have no hesitation in recommending Mr. Merrick to any position of responsibility.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed.) Allen J. Macsween.

Sir:

I beg to refer again to your letter of the 8th instant and my reply of the 19th, regarding manual training instruction at Squamish Residential School, North Vancouver, B.C.

Mr. Merrick called this morning with the enclosed copies of testimonials in support of his application. The Rev. Father Maillard, Principal of the Sechelt Residential School happened to be in this office when Mr. Merrick called, and was able to tell Mr. Merrick some of his experiences with this branch of the work.

Father Maillard is in complete agreement with me that the practical instruction given by Mr. Tebb is invaluable, and fits the pupils for the work they will find most useful after they leave school.

The Squamish School is in charge of Sisters, consequently the discipline has been lacking in manual training classes because the instructor cannot receive the same support as where there is a male principal. Father Maillard advises me that Mr. Tebb has always insisted upon strict discipline in his classes and knows how to handle Indian pupils and much of his success is due to it.

I believe Mr. Barry was agreeably surprised when he inspected the Sechelt School, to find that the pupils knew the name of every tool, how to spell it and its use, which he had not found in other schools; also that some dovetailing work the pupils had done, could not be done as well...

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McGill.

For the past five years, the Department has provided a Manual Training Instructor at the Squamish Indian Residential School, North Vancouver, B. C. Approximately forty (40) lessons are given during the ten teaching months of the academic year and an allowance of $5.00 a lesson has been paid the instructor. Funds for this purpose are taken from the "B. C. SPECIAL VOTE".

Mr. Inspector Barry recently reported that the services of the present Manual Training Instructor, Mr. R. H. Shockley, are unsatisfactory, and he has recommended that Mr. Shockley's services be dispensed with. Mr. Agent Ball and the Reverend Principal of the Squamish Residential School concur in this recommendation.

To replace Mr. Shockley, Indian Agent Ball recommends Mr. A. R. Tebbs. For the last two years, Mr. Tebbs has been giving manual training instruction at the Sechelt Indian Residential School, Sechelt, B. C., and his services have been satisfactory as the instruction that he has given the pupils at the Sechelt School has been of a very practical nature and has included boat building; instruction in which is very useful to the Coast Indians.

Inspector Barry recommends the appointment of Charles J. Merrick, 1248 Keith Road, Hollyburn, B. C. This man is thirty-one years of age, holds a B. C. Manual Training certificate and, for the past four and a half years has been in charge of manual training in the district of North Vancouver, but has recently been discharged owing to the necessity for economy.

I would appreciate your direction as to what action should be taken with reference to the appointment of a Manual Training Instructor at the Squamish Residential School.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 25th instant regarding tools stolen from the manual training department of the Squamish Residential School.

I enclose a list of the tools herewith. The last item, a warehouse coat, was the personal property of the manual training instructor, C.J. Merrick.

It was discovered that one of the pupils Joe Charlie, aged 14, went to the teacher Sister Alix on December 29th and told her another Sister had sent him for the keys to the manual training school so that he could go in and close a window which had been left open. The Sister handed over the keys which were returned shortly after and nothing more was thought of it until school re-opened when the loss was discovered. The pupils were questioned and all denied knowledge of the theft but suspicion centred on Joe Charlie who was brought to this office for questioning. He finally confessed that he had not been sent for the keys at all, had taken the tools and hidden them under the school and later that day sold them to two white boys for fifty cents. These boys can not be traced as he said he had never seen them before or since. There is evidence to support the matter of the fifty cents because he took another boy to North Vancouver and spent it on soft drinks - which was verified later.

I was in favour of sending the boy to the Industrial School, but the Sister Superior begged that he should not leave her school. After consulting the father of the boy who was very disappointed and angry, I acceded to the Sister's Superior request on condition that the boy was properly punished by his father. Unofficially I may say he was given a wholesome thrashing and later he apologized to his teachers and will refund $10.00 towards purchasing new tools. The manual training instructor also asked that the boy remain and continue his instruction, although he had lost a coat in the deal.

Possibly the Department will consider that this matter was handled in rather an unorthodox manner, but personally I do not like to see Indian boys sent to the Provincial Industrial School as it does not improve them in the least--rather the reverse.

The loss will not be very much in excess of the $10.00 and every effort will be made to locate the boys who bought the tools, though I doubt if we shall meet with any........

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
any success.

I intended reporting this matter fully, when it became necessary to request authority to replace the tools.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[F.J.C.Ball]

On December 29th, 1933 Joe Charlie, age 14, a pupil of the above school, secured the keys for the manual training department from one of the teachers, Sister Alix, on the pretence of closing a window. The keys were returned in a short time.

The loss of the tools was not discovered till school re-opened. When questioned the pupils denied knowing anything about it and suspicion fell on Joe Charlie, who was brought to the Indian Office and questioned. He admitted taking the tools, hiding them under the school and later selling them for fifty cents to two white boys, strangers to him. These boys were unable to be traced. Second hand stores in North Vancouver were checked but no trace of the tools were discovered.

After consulting the boy's father, Charlie Antoine, the Indian Agent acceded to the request of the Sister's Superior, that the boy be allowed to remain in her school instead of being sent to the Industrial School. It was also the wish of the manual training instructor that this boy continue his training at the Squamish School.

Joe Charlie is refunding ten dollars towards the purchasing of new tools to replace those stolen.

The Indian Agent,

Madam:

As soon as possible after March 31st next, you should forward to the Department a detailed report regarding the vocational training that is given at the Squamish Residential School. This report should contain the following information:

Sir:

MEMORANDUM

TO: The Indian Commissioner

FROM: The District School Inspector

Re: Manual Training Instructor
Squamish Residential School

I refer to Mr. Neary's letter of January 26th concerning the grant towards the manual training instructor's salary at the above mentioned school. This teacher instructs manual training three half days per week and gardening for 1/2 hours on two days. He is the only male member of the staff.

I have not had an opportunity of seeing him give lessons but have examined the work of his pupils. This appears to be somewhat better than average.

This school is badly in need of a male member on the staff and I believe that encouragement should be given to the school to retain him.

I recommend that the grant of $50.00 per month be increased to $85.00.

R.F. Davey,
Dist. School Inspector.
Air Mail

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 167-1-11 (W 1)
Re: Manual Training Instructor
Squamish Residential School

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of January 26th and application of Robert Chaland for appointment as manual training teacher at the Squamish Residential School, I am enclosing a memorandum dated February 2nd from District School Inspector Davey in this connection. You will note that Mr. Davey recommends Mr. Chaland's employment and payment of a grant of $85.00 a month to the school towards his salary.

Mr. Davey is away on an inspection tour but I understand that he interviewed Mr. Chaland and considers him suitable for the position and although it is doubtful if his services as manual training instructor would warrant a grant of $85.00 a month from the B.C. Special Vote it is doubtful if the school will continue to employ him unless assistance to this extent is given. As stated by Mr. Davey, the school is badly in need of a male member on the staff, in view of which I concur in his recommendation, the arrangement to be subject to review before the next academic year.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

end.

Sir:

I have examined the teeth of the children at St. Paul's School, Squamish Mission Indian Reservation, Vancouver Agency, and find that nearly all of the have teeth which are crowded, crooked, decayed or carious requiring the attention of a dentist.

Decayed teeth in children result in tooth-ache, offensive breath, diseases of the gums and jaws, indigestion from badly masticated food and in poor general health. There results an increased susceptibility to disease and often a marked falling off in ability to study.

Subject to the approval of the Department I would respectfully suggest the name of Dr. E. Fraser Allen, an ex-service man, 825 Granville Street, Vancouver, B. C., as a legally qualified and professionally efficient dentist. His father is on the staff of the Department of Customs, Vancouver, B. C.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your two letters of the 30th ultimo, with reference to the medical and dental treatment required by the pupils of the Squamish Mission Indian Residential School and enclosing reports from the medical officer for the Vancouver agency regarding the best means for having the necessary treatment carried out.

Only those pupils considered by the doctor, the principal and yourself as requiring operations or treatment should be dealt with. When the work has been completed you should forward properly certified vouchers covering the amount of the hospital fees due for each pupil. It is hoped that no unnecessary expenditure will be incurred and that the cost involved will be kept down to the lowest possible point.

Regarding the dental attention, I have to request that you will state what arrangements it is intended to make in having the work carried out. Would the dentist perform the work at the school or would the pupils visit his office? I may say that the only dental work which the Department can allow is extractions and fillings and only in those cases absolutely requiring the same. Please state what fees Dr. Allan, the dentist recommended by the medical officer to perform the work, would charge for each extraction and for each filling, using amalgam for the purpose. You should also state approximately the number of children whose teeth require attention. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, regarding the dental work required by the pupils of the Squamish Indian Residential School and enclosing a communication from the medical officer, Dr. Wilson, covering an estimate made by Dr. Allen, dentist, of the cost and the amount of work to be performed.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange with Dr. E. Fraser Allen, 210-211 Coughlan Building, Vancouver, to perform the dental work absolutely required in the case of each pupil. We note that the cost of fillings and extractions, which work only is to be performed, is as follows:

Amalgam or porcelain without local anaesthetic ............... $1.00
Amalgam or porcelain with local anaesthetic .................. 1.50
Extractions, without local anaesthetic ......................... .50
Extractions with local anaesthetic for nerve blocking ...... 1.00

All material used, equipment and transportation is to be included in the above quotations and the work is to be done at the school. The dental work should be performed at a time satisfactory to the principal and when it will not interfere with the regular routine or classroom work of the school.

When the work has been completed, you should forward a properly certified voucher, in duplicate, covering the amount due Dr. Allen for his services. This voucher should show the number of fillings and extractions, separately, and also whether done with or without local anaesthetics. The Department will rely on you to see that no unnecessary expenditure is incurred. It is to be understood that fillings are to be done only to permanent teeth and then only where absolutely necessary. Owing to the cost involved, due discretion should be used regarding the necessity for each filling and extraction performed.

As the pupils of this school are members of the Squamish Band, the cost of the dental work will be charged to the interest funds at the credit of that band, Account No. 54.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

C. C. Perry, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Room 402 Holden Building,
Vancouver, B. C.

October 5, 1927.

Dear Dr. Baker:

With reference to earlier correspondence, I should be grateful if you would arrange to perform the dental services required at the present time by the pupils of the Coqualeetza and Squamish Indian Residential Schools. The fees allowed by this Department are at the rate of 35 cents for each extraction and $1.00 for each amalgam filling. More expensive fillings are not authorized. In the case of temporary teeth only extractions can be allowed. The work shall be performed at the school. All material, equipment and transportation expenses should be supplied by yourself.

If you accept this proposal, please inform me and communicate with the principals of the schools and ascertain when it will be convenient for you to undertake the work. The principals in question and their addresses are as follows: Rev. G. H. Riley, Principal, Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, Saske, B.C., and Rev. Sister Mary Amy, Principal, Squamish Indian Residential School, North Vancouver, B.C. When I receive your answering communication, I shall inform the principals and local Indian agents and request them to assist you in every possible way.

When the work has been finished at a school, please prepare, in duplicate, a list giving the name of pupil receiving dental attention, and the number of fillings and extractions performed for each. The list for Coqualeetza School should be certified by the principal, who will forward it to the Department for payment, while the list for the Squamish School should be certified by the principal and handed to the local Indian agent.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Madam,

The Department has engaged a nurse with university training in public health for duty in the Vancouver Agency, and it is expected that she will begin her work about August 1st, 1930. In the course of her duties she will visit your school, and it is desired to recommend her to your courtesy. The purpose of her visits will be to confer with you and the person in charge of the health of the pupils on matters which relate to their welfare. It is not expected that she will be able to offer many useful suggestions on her first visit, but with your kind co-operation she should prove of great assistance to you after she has gained experience. The nurse who has received this appointment has been in the employ of the Department before and has our fullest confidence in respect to qualifications, tact, and good judgment. It is hoped that you will receive great benefit from her services.

Sir:

Visited the Squamish Residential and Day Schools February 17th and 18th. Made the usual class room inspection and gave class room talks.

General health conditions were much the same as on other visits, except that two of the children were in bed with a bad cold.

Cleanliness - reported cases of dirty heads among the boarders to the Sister in charge. With day pupils sent home slip with directions for clearing up the condition, will visit the homes in the course of a few days. Most of the pupils are fairly clean.

It would be advisable to have the Medical Officer if possible check tonsil cases and general health before the children go home on holidays at mid-term. Enclosed find individual school reports and recommendation as to teeth.

Sister Superior reports irregular attendance of several of the pupils, list enclosed.

If the Department considers it necessary to have the matters referred to in the fourth paragraph attended to by Dr. Willis, I will so instruct him.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
F.J.C. Ball, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Vancouver, B.C.

Sir,

Visited the Squamish Residential and Day School April 29th. Made the usual individual examination and spoke to the children individually of personal habits and conditions to be corrected.

Gave three class room talks, - Diet and care of teeth. At the time of my visit several of the children were absent from school, the teaching Sister informs me the irregular attendance is a regular habit with certain families. Visited the homes and found no legitimate reason for absence with the exception of one. Possibly if the Sister-in-Charge would report the week's absentees to the office a check up and consequent lessening of the number would result.

Cleanliness - Heads show improvement as to cleanliness both in the Residential and Day Schools.

General Health - Fair, a list of the children it would be advisable to have the Doctor examine enclosed.

Yours truly,

(Sgd) H.E. Gerry
Travelling Nurse

SIR:-

I beg to submit the following Report in connection with the Squamish Mission Indian Residential School:-

Since taking over the duties of Medical Officer for the Vancouver-New Westminster Health Unit, I have paid four visits to this Residential School. On November 16th, I made a most complete inspection of the premises, including the dormitories and the manual training department. On November 22nd, I timed my visit so as to be present when the mid-day meal was being eaten.

STAFF.

The Mother Superior is a most courteous lady and seems to be vitally interested in the health and general welfare of the children under her care. She seems to be frugal, but at the same time appears to be anxious that her pupils shall be comfortable and that the diet they receive shall be reasonably well balanced. She seems to be sincere.

During the course of my visits, I was given every opportunity to thoroughly inspect the whole Institution. The entire Staff did everything they could to assist me.

FOOD.

The meals served the children seem to be better than they would receive in their homes. There appears to be plenty to eat, although there is no waste.

The Mother Superior gave me an outline of the average daily menu as follows:-

Breakfast - 7:30 A.M.
Porridge with one-half cup of fresh milk.
Sugar in the porridge.
Bread and peanut butter, ordinary butter once or twice per week.
Weak tea with milk.

Lunch - 12 Noon.
Meat
Potatoes
Beans once or twice a week instead of potatoes.
One raw carrot per child
One apple
One-quarter loaf of bread.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
File No. B-7-C.

Four O'Clock Lunch.
One Piece of Bread.
One Apple.

Supper - 6 P.M.
Potatoes, boiled or baked.
Apple Sauce, jelly or preserves.
Bread
Cocoa.

On November 22nd, I was present during lunch and know that the menu was adhered to for that particular meal.

SANITATION ETC.

The whole Institution was clean and well kept. The dormitories were tidy, and although perhaps a little crowded, were above reproach.

In conclusion I will say that from personal observations, I have made, I am of the opinion that the children are well nourished, well looked after and give one the impression of contentment. Most certainly they are not starved or neglected in any way.

Your obedient servant,

A. L. McQuarrie.
Medical Superintendent.

September 11th, 1934.

Dear Mr. Bell,

Doctor McQuarrie has recommended a five-day dental clinic at the Squamish Indian Residential School, partly for residential pupils and partly for day pupils and younger children of the adjoining Reserves.

The Department is pleased to provide such clinic but thinks that four days' work might be found to cover the necessities. Miss Berry will apparently have charge of the clinic and it will be greatly appreciated if she can find herself able to complete it in four days.

The rate allowed is $30 per day, net, and is to cover any expenses for materials or travelling costs which will be small. The class of work required is extractions with local anaesthetic and the cheaper type of fillings. The department is accustomed to receiving the co-operation of the dentist in a good day's work.

It is desired that a complete separation be made between the accounts for residential school pupils and for the other children as the funds are provided from different allotments. All accounts will be endorsed by Miss Berry and certified by yourself. It is not necessary that a list of the pupils names should reach Ottawa, but it is essential that the number of different operations

in Latin, and his director in the ecclesiastical training, and where also Mr. Hone would have to give class to the boys of the school every day. No demur was then made to that by Mr. Hone, in my presence. In the course of conversation I added that, if he would understand the Latin at the first sight or reading and if he would give full satisfaction in everything, most probably he would be through his preparation to the priesthood in three years.

On the second day of August Mr. Hone came to St. Mary's of his own free will and on the 3rd. August he commenced to teach the boys of the school two hours in the forenoon and two hours in the afternoon, receiving himself every day a class of Latin philosophy from the priest I had appointed to that purpose.

On the 25th. August Mr. Hone asked leave to go to his parents and pass a week or two with them. On the 12th. September he came back to the Mission and did resume his former regulation.
regulation, except that he had only two hours class to the boys in the afternoon. Revd. Father Morgan, an Irish Priest, was then giving two hours class to them in the forenoon. Mr. Hone had everyday, except Sunday, a class of one hour duration given to him by his professor of philosophy.

On the 23rd. December, Mr. Hone went to Vancouver to pass the Christmas Holy Days with his parents and did not return any more.

The above is a correct statement of facts on which Mr. Hone takes ground for claiming a salary as teacher for over four months. Has he really a right to some salary?

In his application on the 25th. February 1894 to be received in my diocese as above mentioned, Mr. Hone asks the favour to be adopted by me for my Diocese. To adopt means to take a stranger into one's family as a son. To be adopted by a Bishop for his Diocese means, in the case of Mr. Hone, to be received as a young
young aspirant to the Priesthood for my Diocese and consequently to be trained by me as one of my future priests and in the way I think best in order to render him worthy of the priesthood.

So have I understood the application and demand of Mr. Hone, and I have acted accordingly. I sent him to St. Mary's to be trained there to the Priesthood and in order to put him to work in acquiring the virtues and qualifications required in a Priest, I gave him so much time every day to pray in the chapel with the Priests of St. Mary's, I gave him so much time every day to teach the boys in the school, so much time to study his Latin and philosophy, I selected a professor to explain said philosophy to him during one hour every day.

The teaching of the boys given to Mr. Hone was only to be a means to train him in the acquisition of the virtues and the disposition required in a priest as a spiritual and religious adviser of the people. I had no
no need of Mr. Hone for a teacher. Brother Collins, an Irish Teacher, has been the teacher of the boys these last six years and said Brother Collins was still at the Mission all the time Mr. Hone remained there. It is not true that I have given a month's notice to a teacher employed at St. Mary's school in order to make room for Mr. Hone. No teacher has been dismissed from St. Mary's school in April 1894, none in May, none in June, none in July, and none in August. Every man and child at St. Mary's may testify to this. Brother Collins was the teacher there, and when on the 25th. August Mr. Hone went down to Vancouver for a rest, Brother Collins resumed his former school occupation.

When in our first interview at New Westminster I said to Mr. Hone that if he would understand the Latin at the first sight or reading and if he would give full satisfaction in everything, most probably he would be through his preparation to the Priesthood in three years, the realization of
of this rested on the sole and essential if. But when Mr. Hone was put to the Latin of the book of philosophy, he was found deficient, he could not understand well such Latin nor translate it correctly. When also it was found that Mr. Hone had some aversion to many things required from him in order to train him to a true sacerdotal spirit my former word and saying "if" was not applicable to him. Thence came the declaration made to him that six years would be probably necessary to the priesthood.

The various complaints, though exaggerated, brought forward by Mr. Hone in his letter to you show indeed that he had to take time in acquiring the interior perfection to which an aspirant to the priesthood is bound to reach in order to become worthy. Dear Sir:

I beg to lay the following facts concerning the Roman Catholic Indian School at Mission, and the nature of my connection with it for your consideration and assistance.

I must inform you to commence my statement, that I became a convert to the Roman Catholic Church a few years ago, and I went to the College of the Benedictine Fathers at Mount Angel, Oregon in 1892 to study for the priesthood. I remained at College two years when finding my own resources would not permit of my continuing my studies there this year without pecuniary assistance, I did as other clerical students do, endeavoured to get them paid by a Bishop, on condition of devoting ones future labours to the advancement of his diocese.
Having relatives resident in B.C., I naturally applied to Bishop Durieu of New Westminster last April to that effect, and received an answer from him in reply, "That he would be very happy to adopt me for the continuance of my studies on condition of my eventually labouring in his diocese, if I could send him a written reference from the Benedictine Fathers as to my proficiency in translating just an ordinary Latin book and gave general good conduct etc.

As I was engaged in translating Antons Ceasar at the time, the Benedictine Fathers sent Bishop Durieu a very satisfactory reply in every respect; and I received another letter from him stating that the reference was perfectly satisfactory in every way, and would I like to come to Westminster at once. As Bishop Durieu had not given me particulars (as I had requested him) as to where I should continue my studies etc., I wrote him again to that effect, but in reply he evaded giving me a definite answer saying
he would explain all when I came to Westminster.

On vacation in June (with much difficulty and expense owing to the railway strike at the time) I came to Westminster fully expecting Bishop Durieu (as is customary) would reimburse me for the outlay, but nothing of the kind, and to my surprise he informed me that he had made arrangements for me to study philosophy and theology at Mission and to teach the school there, and when I demurred at not having been told these arrangements before leaving Oregon, I was told (after having lost other and as it proved then, better chances there, and having come a long and expensive journey on his account) "Well, that was all he had to offer me". He however assured me by going up to Mission I should get through all my studies in three years, and was very desirous "On account of my health" that I should first spend a month's holiday with my friends (And as I afterwards learned to enable him to give
a month's notice to a teacher employed at the Mission School).

I went up to Mission on August 1st, and had the entire charge of the school with attendance at all the spiritual exercises of the Oblate Community and study of Senerinos Philosophy imposed on me. I continued all these duties for a month and then owing to the constant mental strain without the least time for relaxation or exercise I became so unwell from dyspepsia that I had to return again to my friends to recuperate.

After two weeks absence I received a letter from Father Chirouse the Director of the School, stating that Bishop Durieu had sent Father Morgan then up to Mission to help me with the school, (though I learnt afterwards Father Morgan's presence there was owing to the strong condemnation by the judge of his conduct in intimidating a witness in the penitentiary scandal) I however returned shortly afterwards and resumed my studies in the morning.
I may remark here that I always experienced great difficulty in obtaining instruction from the Fathers there, owing to their very Frenchified Latin pronunciation, and their ignorance of any but the most crude and simple words in the English language.

It is utterly impossible that they (including Bishop Durieu) can teach Boys English when they can neither speak it or write it correctly themselves, and though they draw two thousand dollars yearly from the Government for the proper maintenance and instruction of the twenty two boys in their school. Bishop Durieu in a recent letter to myself states that "He never has at any time paid a salary to a teacher for them" and as they do not spend a cent of the money to clothe them, but leave them to be insufficiently and wretchedly clad by their friends. I can only surmise at what they do with the money. I know that I frequently spoke to Father Chirouse about their not having suitable books for geography and other
other studies, and complained about the supply of books being insufficient and dilapidated, but to no effect. I know too, that they were frequently employed out in the fields when according to the code of rules sent by the Government for their regulation, they were supposed to be in school acquiring an education. I purposely omitted signing the marks in the record for their attendance, because I did not wish to mark down their being in attendance at school when they were not.

I returned again and taught school in the afternoon rising at five in the morning attending all spiritual exercises of the community and studying myself in the morning and to continue my statement my relatives desired me to ask Bishop Durieu in November if he was willing (to do as other Bishops do) provide me with clothes etc. especially as I was chiefly employed in teaching his School, and he had never contributed a cent towards my expenses so far. I did so, and was told by Bishop Durieu that he would supply me
me with clothes from the store of cast off garments given them for the Lay Brothers to work in, and a pair of shoes when those I had were on the ground, and I must not imagine that I could continue wearing linen shirts as I had been accustomed to, but in future a flannel shirt must serve me both summer and winter. He would also require me to study and teach school four years. He also must insist on my making no further excuse to Father Chirouse opening and examining all my letters before I received or sent any away. I must fast more rigorously too, I asked for time to consider these conditions. I may state that the living there is frugal and scanty in the extreme. I had nothing but bread and coffee, salt salmon and potatoes on the many fast days and I could not fast more than I did then. I may mention too that Father Chirouse, the Director of the School, and who was also appointed my spiritual adviser, is the same priest who so unmercifully beat a poor Indian woman some time.
time ago and was imprisoned in consequence.

On Dec. 20th, I received intimation through a letter from Bishop Durieu to one of the Fathers at the Mission "That I should then be required to study and teach school six years instead of three as first agreed on. I must at once allow Father Chirouse to examine all my letters and fast more strictly. I at once said these conditions were entirely different to those under which I had been induced to teach their school five months, and that I should not continue there any longer unless I remained until I could obtain some position elsewhere.

I learnt a few days later that Bishop Durieu had again written stating that I might remain as long as I liked, providing that I taught school, but I must not expect to receive a cent in payment from him. I however came to Vancouver and consulted with my relatives, who advised me to
demand payment of Bishop Durieu for the time I had been employed by him under misrepresentation to teach his school.

In the meantime I received a letter from Father Chirouse stating that he was awaiting my return to open up school again.

Bishop Durieu steadily refuses to recompense me in any way for the tuition I have given his school or for the loss I have sustained, and I leave it to you, Sir, to judge whether recompense should not be given me, for the time I have taught the school. I do not include in this the cost, the loss of other positions, the expense of travelling and the wear and tear of my clothes etc. in the same cause. And I trust that in any way it is in your power to aid me against this injustice being perpetrated on me you will kindly do so. And oblige

Yours very respectfully,

(Sgd) Sylvester Hone.

P. S. I omitted to mention when referring to
to the management of the School that I was never entrusted to make out any reports or communicate with the Government in any way concerning the school, although I was always referred to when strangers came there as "Our teacher".

BRITISH AGRICULTURE.

The Board of Agriculture has just issued a curious and suggestive report. In spite of the most sudden change has come over British agriculture. The report is for the year ending on April 1st, 1896, and shows that within the year the area of Great Britain devoted to wheat has been diminished by somewhat more than 2 per cent., in percentage it is 20.5, and in acres 30,330 acres. The decrease is uniform throughout the country, every county practically in England, since wheat beans are grown only in some areas, and therefore a great deal of the whole wheat area over 30 per cent., is English. This is clear proof that feeding sheep has already gone far. It approached too much for the British farmer to attempt to sustain. So great a diminution could not prevent from being due to certain causes, but must be the result of a settled conviction of the hopelessness of the contest, or the strong feeling against countries where land so much cheaper and agricultural labor not equally dear than our own can produce the best. The natural question ensues, To what is the land hereafter to be devoted? What more productive crop than wheat growing? There is a considerable increase in the acreage of potatoes, and an increase also of the number of "improved pastures," though the grass is still not sown as far in Scotland as in other parts of Great Britain. The increase in the number of pigs raised. This increase is about an equivalent to about one-fifth of the wheat area. The American farmer should be much interested in this information. While he discovers that without the advantage of high land values, he cannot grow as much wheat as he could if the prices were higher, he must also discover that the wheat market is wider open to him than ever before. He cannot avoid advertising his product all over the world, about to be made upon the American farmer. If he wishes to have his work declared non-commercial, it must be stronger than ever before.

I have the honor to bring to your notice the annexed letter of the Rev. Father Benson, Principal of St. Mary's Indian Boarding School in the Fraser River Agency.

In their desire to lead on their offsprings more and more in the path of civilization, the Fraser River Indians are most anxious to see their children educated in an Industrial School. This school is deserving of great credit for all the good it has accomplished in favor of the Indians who attended it since its opening in 1862. Besides its central location and other advantages, its efficiency is equal in all respects to that of the other Industrial Schools in British Columbia.

Having to meet in our Indian School a good many new exigencies with which we cannot cope without the benevolent help of the Dominion Government, we humbly beg of Your Lordship to lay our case before the proper Authorities.

During the last few years, the number of our pupils has almost doubled and is still increasing. This is due to the consoling fact that the Fraser Indians have made considerable progress in civilization. The old pupils of our school are now fathers and mothers of families; they understand better the advantages of education and wish to have their children properly educated. Therefore they ask us to take them in our school expecting us to supply tuition, board, books etc. To answer to their praiseworthy wish of advancing in civilization we used all the efforts in our power to give the pupils the training best adapted to make of them good and useful people in every way.

We receive from the Dominion Government

a grant of $60 per capita for 40 pupils. This is certainly a great help for the school, but as I have before, the number of the pupils having almost doubled, it is now very insufficient even to keep the children we received, and besides, with great regret, we have been obliged to refuse many applications only for not being able to afford their board.

We are, therefore, compelled to humbly beg of the Indian Department to endow us as a Government Industrial School with an allowance of $130 per capita, which is granted to the other industrial schools. I beg to call your attention to the smallness of the grant given by the Dominion Government to the Indian Boarding School at St. Mary's Mission in the Fraser River Agency. The rate allowed is 60 dollars for each of sixty pupils. Experience has proved that for 60 dollars a year a pupil cannot be provided with board, clothing, books, stationary, medical attendance, medicine &c., to say nothing of keeping the school up to the high standard demanded by the Government and expected by the parents of the children.

Entirely at our own expense we have erected at a cost of $18,000.00 two separate school buildings, one for girls under the management of four Sisters of St. Ann, the other for the boys under two Fathers and two lay teachers. There is ample accommodation for forty-five children in each school.

In our anxiety for the advancement of the Natives we expended this large sum under the impression that the Federal Government would furnish the means to carry on these schools for the benefit of an Indian Catholic population of over 1300.

A careful census taken this year shows that there are 1635 Indians living in the valley of the Fraser River from Yale to its mouth and that 1356 are members of the Catholic church.

Included amongst those Catholics are many heads of families who were educated at St. Mary's Boarding School, that school having been established in 1861, upwards of 25 years ago, and having been educated there themselves they wish to send their children there likewise. Seventy-seven of their children are at present inmates of St. Mary's School.
The golden rule of the Federal Government being, not to disturb the faith of the Indians but to leave them to the guidance of those who converted them to Christianity, I hope and trust that you will help those Catholics to have their children educated in the school of their faith and choice, placing them on a level with the Indians who send their children to Coqualeetza Methodist school at Chilliwack.

To The Honorable Clifford Sifton, M.P.
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Honorable Sir,

Knowing your desire to be informed on all that concerns the affairs which come under your administration, and being convinced of your readiness to deal justly in all matters, we respectfully call your attention, as Superintendent General of Indian affairs, to the needs of some of our Indians in the matter of education as well as to the insufficiency of the present grant allowed to St. Mary's Mission Indian Boarding School.

We have no hesitation to acknowledge, as we ought, what the Government of Canada has done, when, at the request of the several Denominations, which carry on schools, it has granted educational help for the Indians in British Columbia.

This very commendable action on the part of the Government, apart from aiding to civilize the wards under its charge, is destined, more than any other measure, to promote among them lasting peace and happiness. In adopting this manner of dealing with the Indians the Canadian Government has earned for itself the reputation of wisdom, prudence and humaneness. In being guided by a spirit of tolerance and respect for the religious convictions of the Indians, the Federal authorities have shown that they understood the character of these people, who when once converted, are generally deeply religious.

If the same policy shall in future pervade the legislation for Indians, and guide those who are commissioned to apply the laws, the authorities will always find a docile and submissive people.

When in pursuance of this policy the governments, in the past, have
granted pecuniary aid to the school authorities of various denominations, they did so under the conviction that the help voted for the Indians would more surely and efficaciously reach those for whom it was intended. The Indians themselves understand it in that light and we know from experience that money thus spent for them is the most profitable to them, since it reaches them through the channels of their acknowledged and revered guides, who know best how to devote it to their highest interests. The sums thus granted cannot be considered excessive when it is considered that the Indians in British Columbia have handed over their former lands so peaceably. Moreover, it is well to remember that as our Indians receive no allowance of any kind, other than that for education, they are obliged to furnish themselves with food, clothing etc., for which they have to pay and so they are an inconsiderable source of revenue to the Dominion since they help by their labor to the development of commerce, and since they share in bearing the custom taxes which go to the Dominion.

While rendering due homage to the good intention of past governments as to their Indian policy in British Columbia, we feel it however, our duty to take exception to one feature of the course followed heretofore. We beg leave to expose our views before you.

Since the government granted pecuniary aid for the education of the Indians in this Province, it seems to us that the plan of distribution ought to have been so devised that all those Indians who are desirable to improve by education, could have shared proportionately in these grants. Again, since the government made it a rule to make the grants to the denominational schools as such, this distribution, to be equitable, should have been made in such a manner that the amounts, allowed for each Denomination, should have been in
proportion to the number of adherents of each denomination.

Such, however, we regret to say, has not been the course followed. We show this to be the case by means of the accompanying table marked "A" (see at Reference attached to back).

Proportionate Distribution of School grants in the Province of British Columbia.

This table (A) has been prepared from the Annual Report of the Department of Indian Affairs for 1896.

Taking the official figures given in the Departmental Report, 1st as to the population in each agency, 2nd as to the number of Catholics in each agency, and 3rd as to the school grants, and comparing the amounts granted with the numbers of Indians belonging to each Denomination we see:

That the proportionate amount allowed to the Protestants by far exceeds that given to the Catholics.

The number of Catholic Indians in B.C. = 12523

Protestant in B.C. = 6769

The total school grant for Catholics was $29,000

Protestants was 22,060

If these sums were divided equally amongst the Catholics and Protestants respectively, the Protestants would each receive 41 per cent more than the Catholics. This is a very sensible difference. The Catholic Indians having the same rights as the Protestant they should be treated on equal terms and we know of no reason why the governments, in the past, should have acted with such discrimination in this matter, nor is there any reason why this inequality of treatment should not be removed by the present administration.

Now, any one will naturally think that the grants given to a school or a particular agency are to be devoted to the education of the children of that agency.

Again, as the grants are given to the Denominational schools as such, one also will naturally infer that the school authorities will devote the subsidies received to the children of the particular denomination under which the school is placed.

But in the case under consideration neither the Methodist nor the Church of England School can show a number of children of their respective denominations and belonging to the agency, which could justify them in receiving the grants which they receive at present.

On the other hand the Catholic school received an amount totally inadequate to the number of Catholics who are living on the Agency, and who have a right to share equally in the public money devoted to their agency.

Why should the other schools, especially the Coqualeetza Institute of Chilliwack, receive amounts out of all proportion to the number of children whom the authorities can justly lay a claim to? It is impossible to answer this question unless we should admit that the government granted this disproportionate sum to enable the Methodist school authorities to carry on proselytism among the Catholic Indians.
We do not wish, however, to affirm that such is the intention of the government, but what we may affirm, and, what can easily be proved, is, that the school authorities of the Coqualeetza Institute, have drawn and are still trying to draw Catholic children to their school, which is a course entirely opposed to the spirit of the Indian legislation, as may be seen by Orders in Council issued at various times, and more recently on November 10th, 1894* A.Y.L. (14).

As a conclusion of all that we have laid before your enlightened consideration, Honorable Sir, and on the strength of the justice of our demand, we ask that the Government increase the annual grant to St. Mary's Mission Boarding School.

In order that this School may be placed on a proper footing of efficiency as a Boarding School, and to enable it to answer better to the requirements of so many who have a claim upon it, we ask that the Government give a yearly allowance of $100. per capita for at least 70 children.

After what we have shown on table 'B', of this memorial, we need not insist further on the necessity of providing for a larger number of pupils than this school was able to receive up to the present.

Now, as to the increase of the per capita grant from $60. to $100., we must say that the present allowance of $60. is entirely inadequate to defray all the expenses for a child's keep. This sum hardly paid for the board, and the school has to furnish the children with books, provide fuel, light and clothing. etc. etc.

Moreover, considering that the Mission has done so much for the instruction of the Indians of the Fraser River since 1862, date when the school was established, and, considering what it is still
doing for the same purpose, the Government ought not to defer any longer the granting of the much needed increase, namely $100. for 70 children, instead of the present all too insufficient allowance.

We have the honor to be,

Honorable Sir,-

Your humble servants,-

In reply to your letter, asking for information as to the probable source of the contagion causing Diphtheria at St. Mary's Mission School, I beg to say that I have investigated the conditions thoroughly, & am obliged to conclude that the late Rev. Dear Mr. McDonald,

I should have notified you yesterday of the bad state of affairs at Old Mission, only I had to go to North Bend, and consequently had to put off writing till today.

Father Marshal contracted Diphtheria—a most malignant type—on Sunday. I saw him on Monday & gave him a maximum dose of Antitoxine. On Tuesday morning he had evidently attempted to sit up in bed and the effort had been too much for the weakened heart. He must have fallen back on the pillows and died instantly.

Two of the Indian girls then took the disease; but prompt measures have succeeded in checking the mischief. I am living in fear & trembling; for of course there was plenty of opportunity for the disease to get all through the place. I will notify you at once should any more cases develop.

Dear Sir,

I gladly received the news to be allowed to enroll more children to St. Mary's Mission School. For many years I have been traveling among the different Indian tribes and lived with them their own life. Often I wondered why not more was done for the education of the poor Indian children. They are so anxious to learn something especially now as the country is getting more and more settled with white people.

Dear Sir, you struck the right thing when you had the department to investigate how many Indian children there were of age to go to school and who had no opportunity of doing so and everybody was amazed to see that the children admitted to the schools were only a minority.
At once you went to work and great changes have been made for the betterment of the schools already existing and new schools have been built.

Grasping your idea I tried it many times to interest the officials of the department to interest themselves with the needs of St. Mary's Mission. I do not know how they never succeeded to appease you. They make fine promises and that was all.

The Oblate Father of the North West had spoken to me often times of the great interest you take yourself in this great question of education. I said to myself why not write myself directly to Mr. D. Scott, when I knew that Rev. Fr. Welsh was at Ottawa I did not hesitate a moment to do so. At once you took steps and it did not take you very long to favor our request with a grant for 15 more children.

Many thanks to you, dear sir, for your great kindness.

As I tell you above I tried the authorities to interest themselves in my plan. But they
cost me very dearly. My intention was to enlarge the buildings of St. Mary's Mission School for the purpose of taking in more children. We drew up the plans ourselves, but that did not suit the Rev. Father J. Welch our superintendent. He wanted the things done properly and by an architect. Himself and our Indian Agent and between our Inspector, Mrs. Dickburn went to interview the architect, Gardner & Murray of New Westminster, to draw plans for St. Mary's Mission School. The plans were drawn and approved by those gentlemen but between rejected by the Council of the O.M.I. on the ground that they had not the means to pay for the proposed buildings. Now the plans are in my hands and also the bill which amounts to $474.90. Nobody wants to take the responsibility of it and the architects are urging me to settle the account. This puts me in a terrible plight. I have done all I could for the betterment of the institution. All the officials of the department can give testimony of what I have done. The school is in a ten times better condition than what it was when I took charge of it. Never I spent a cent on anything else except my school.
My plans will remain idle for a while yet. My intention was to build on those plans and complete them little by little without going into debts. I wish you could help me. You will not regret it as it will encourage me and my staff to devote ourselves more and more to the education of the Indian children.

This is only a private letter to you, Mr. B. Scott. I do not want to be importunate. I wished only to put the matter before you to see what can be done.

Enclosed also you will find the bill of the architects, Murray and Gordon.

Hoping not to give you too much trouble in your labours.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours very faithfully,

V. Robb O.M.G

Dear Mr. Scott:

During the past two years I have taken considerable interest in our Indian Schools, and visited them frequently. Permit me to draw your attention to St. Mary's Mission, B.C.

I consider St. Mary's an excellent establishment, and yet it only receives the minimum grant $100.00 per annum. Now, you will agree with me, I have no doubt, that the children cannot be properly fed and clothed and educated according to approved standards for such a sum. Likewise it may be said, that the obligation to adequately provide for the education of Indian children is on the State, not on the Church.

Just a year ago you were good enough to increase the number of grant earning pupils at St. Mary's from 60 to 75. I was grateful for this concession and I may assure you that it has been of some financial benefit to us. But I now wish to renew my request made about the same time that the number of grant earners be further increased. St. Mary's is the oldest Boarding School in this Province, and one of the best conducted. For more than half a century it has done splendid work, and at the present time especially is giving the fullest satisfaction to the Department. This school is admirably situated on high ground overlooking the Fraser Valley. The health of the children is again perfect this year, and it is worthy of note that at St. Mary's epidemics are unknown. Our sanitary arrangements have been carefully attended to and a perfect water system has been installed, pure water being piped in from the neighboring hills. The milk supplied to the children is pure and abundant, and you will be pleased to hear that at the request of the Principal the cattle of the school are examined every year, for tuberculosis, by Dr. Dalton, the Provincial Veterinary Inspector. Two years ago we installed a steam heating system at a cost of $8000.00 and for

With regard to the intellectual and moral training received by the children, I need not speak, as it has been highly commended by the Government Inspector, and I think, by both Indian Agents. I would like to state, however, that the children are also educated along various useful lines. The boys, for instance, are taught farming and gardening and a little carpentry, a few are learning shoe-repairing, and three or four of the oldest, plumbing and pipe-fitting. Sir:

I beg to report the serious outbreak of small-pox amongst the Indians in the lower part of this Agency.

On investigating yesterday in company with Dr. McCaffrey I found that so far it was solely amongst the pupils belonging to St. Mary's Mission School. I questioned the children and found that there had been some sickness in the school, and some of these now suffering had been sick for a few days in the school, so they were all sent off home. One child was taken off the train with the rash out on her and she stated that the school authorities had not any doctor to attend her.

I immediately placed the patients and those that were brought in contact with them in quarantine and placed a constable in charge. Some of them were very much adverse to being placed in quarantine stating that they had no means of support so I had to purchase a certain amount of supplies, and made arrangements for the constable to keep them supplied in water, fuel and necessary food. There was another patient who was at home with her parents on Seabird Island Reserve, which family I have also placed in quarantine.

We had an expert sent from the coast who pronounced it small pox of the very worst type.

It is likely to be hard to control as the children were sent from the school to different reserves. There were no less than twelve (12) of these children sent out into different parts of this Agency. Dr. Fort has one of these children under his care at North Bend but has not as yet pronounced the disease as small-pox.

I cannot understand the action taken by the Principal of St. Mary's School at Mission in sending these children back into the reserve to scatter any disease amongst the others, even if they did not know what the dreaded disease was. I understand that there is a Medical Doctor for the Indians at Mission who should have been called and if there was anything wrong the children should have been treated at
at the school instead of being turned out to the four winds as has been done. It seems to be a failing of this school to send children home when anything is wrong with them instead of taking care of them as they should do.

As soon as I learned where this originated I wired Indian Agent Byrne at New Westminster, under whose jurisdiction this school comes, and also the different Provincial Police where any of the children may have got to.

This outbreak will cost a considerable sum to control, but I trust the Department will approve of the action I have taken to prevent any further spread.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th inst., and I do not hesitate to say that, with the exception of the initial paragraph regarding my professional duties to the pupils of St. Mary's Mission Boarding School, about which there can be no dispute, it is the most grossly injurious and unfair I ever had the misfortune to receive.

How can you, Sir, if you possess any sense of justice, on the no-authority of such vague and indeterminate statements as, "it is understood," "it has been said," bring so gravely criminal an accusation against a Medical Health Officer? For, in effect, you accuse me of having, through carelessness and dereliction of duty, been the direct means of causing a wide-spread and serious outbreak of Small Pox throughout the country.

You say, categorically, that I did not take the necessary precautions to stamp out the disease while it was confined to St. Mary's School.

I have been Medical Health Officer for Mission Municipality, as well as the districts of Dewdney & Nicomen, for so many years that I have the right to assume my services have uniformly met with the approbation of the Authorities concerned; and I have no intention of permitting my reputation to be injured in this manner, without making every effort in my power, not only to exonerate myself, but to discover if possible the author or authors of this glaringly false and most injurious scandal.

You say that the Department will be glad to receive an explanation from me; and yet I may, without impertinence, ask what assurance I have that such explanation will meet with the impartial consideration it deserves, seeing that my case has been already prejudged and my conduct severely censured.

The facts, however, are these:

I was away on holiday during the month of July, and my "locum tenens" for the time was Dr. R.H. Port, of Clayburn, B.C.
Towards the latter part of the month, the Rev. Father Rohr, Principal of St. Mary's School, sent for him to examine a pupil who was ill, and on whose skin a suspicious-looking eruption appeared. Dr. Port saw the case, diagnosed Small Pox and promptly quarantined the school.

When I returned on August 1st, I visited the place, saw that the usual warning placards were in position, and that the proper precautions were being taken to prevent the spread of the disease. I may say here that they have exceptional facilities at Old Mission for thoroughly isolating cases of contagious disease, and that these were taken full advantage of on this occasion. Very soon we had 32 cases at St. Mary's School; and not only were these kept in a dormitory by themselves, but Sisters were detailed to attend them, who never, under any circumstances, came in contact with the healthy inmates.

I visited these cases at least once a day in the earlier stages, and two or three times a week while they were convalescing. Not one of those children was permitted to leave the School until the very last one to contract the disease had thoroughly recovered; then every one was scrupulously sponged from head to foot with disinfecting solution; clothes that could not be properly sterilized were burnt, and the whole building cleansed and fumigated in a way that, I do not hesitate to say, could not have been improved upon. Then, and only then, were any of the children allowed to leave St. Mary's; and the fact that no new case developed subsequently, either in the school itself or anywhere in the immediate neighbourhood, showed fairly well that our efforts to restrict the spread of the disease had been satisfactory.

As to the origin of the outbreak, it has been clearly demonstrated that Small Pox existed among the Pemberton Meadows, Anderson Lake and Chilliwack Indians weeks before it appeared at Old Mission.

I, both as physician and Health Officer, took so much pains in visiting the sick Indians and watching individual cases carefully, that I considered I had not only done my duty well, but that my services merited some special recognition from the Department; and I did not hesitate to say so; the more, because, last year, about this time, I, for over two months, visited St. Mary's School, not only every day (and several times at night) but frequently twice a day, as there were in all between 70 to 80 pupils ill with Flu.

Taking those two occasions alone into consideration, I know that I did an amount of professional work for the Department, for which a whole year's salary would be inadequate payment; and the special recognition I receive, is your letter of the 6th!
In accordance with the request from the Department, I have, as physician to the Indians here, given you my version of the Smallpox outbreak, without exaggeration, reservation or concealment of any material fact; and now, speaking with the authority my position as Medical Health Officer gives me, I say emphatically, that not only was everything possible done to limit the spread of the disease, but it was done more thoroughly than is usual in such localized outbreaks.

The Rev. Father Rohr, I am satisfied, did not fail in his duty in any particular; and he gave me strenuous and invaluable assistance throughout the whole course of the epidemic.

It is easy to be wise after the event; and if the disease had been discovered on any of the St. Mary's School pupils soon after leaving the school and before there was any indication of it there, surely no blame could possibly attach to Father Rohr for that. Indeed, it is a well-established fact, that some of the earlier cases were so mild that the patient did not complain of more than a slight malaise, and the ill-defined eruption, in more than one of these, was discovered accidentally.

Regarding my ordinary visits to St. Mary's School, I don't hesitate to affirm that a week seldom passes without my making a professional call there.

I have in this reply, endeavoured to avoid overstepping the bounds of courtesy, and the gravity of the attack on my professional reputation sufficiently warrants an emphatic denial.

The monthly report of my Indian work was interrupted in the Fall of 1918, simply because, on account of the excessive amount of the Flu Epidemic work, I had no time to make out the usual forms; and since then this duty has, I admit, been neglected; for which I tender the Department my regret and apology.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

The Principal thinks five years enough for the average Indian pupil in the class-room from ten years of age to fifteen years. Give them a drilling in the three "R's" and let them go home to make room for others. The idea is extensive rather than intensive.

One strong objection to this method is that you cannot teach an Indian to farm by the time he is fifteen years of age. You may give him Manual Training by the time he is fifteen but you cannot do much with vocational training.

PUPILS-

The pupils are clean, tidy and alert. They were well dressed. The girls sing sweetly. They do not practice calisthenics. The sisters do not see that organized play and a course of physical culture would be beneficial from a health point of view. The principal looks at it from the same standpoint. I have discussed the matter with him. The boys do have, occasionally, a little military drill.

All manual work is good. Writing and map drawing are very good. Geography and history are not attempted, hygiene and composition receive attention. The older pupils do not seem able to reason and to draw conclusions. Problems in arithmetic they cannot do. I have been trying to raise the educational standard but have not succeeded to my satisfaction.

The pupils of this school have a good home and receive every care and attention. The school is fulfilling the purpose for which it was established, viz., the developing of the physical, intellectual and moral nature of Indian children.

R. H. Cairns.

The Rev. J. Welch, of New Westminster, has informed me that he is going East shortly and while there will call at Ottawa to see you about St. Mary's Mission Indian School at Mission City, which as you know is one of the oldest in the Province, and the upkeep has lately become quite a burden as there are so many things necessary to keep in repair. I am not sure whether you ever visited this Institution, but if not I may say that there are three separate buildings, the boys' on the west, the girls' on the east with the Church occupying a position midway between the two.

Lately it had been thought that by the building of a fair-sized structure immediately behind the Church to be used as a kitchen and dining halls for both boys and girls it would help both in minimizing the labour and expense, but as there are other things necessary this idea has been given up and attention is now directed in the matter of a new barn, laundry, and some general repairs to the buildings which need a good overhauling, until such time as they can be replaced by new ones.

Since the Department has taken over the St. George's School at Lytton and it is understood, the Coqualeetza School at Chilliwack, the Reverend Father feels that the same policy should be pursued with regard to St. Mary's Mission. I have explained to him that the Department's policy was against the spending of large sums of money on property for which it did not hold the title.

I do not know how far you will be prepared to go in this matter, but I would say that in the event of your deciding to do anything in the way of taking the school over, the erection of an up-to-date laundry and a new barn, with a small amount of repair work on the present buildings would carry them along for some time.

Having a keen appreciation of your generous nature in connection with all school matters I feel that you will hardly be inclined to disregard Father Welch's appeal but will meet it insofar as it is possible so to do. Honourable Sir:

I have come to Ottawa to ask the Indian Department to make certain important improvements in St Mary's Indian School at Mission, B.C., viz:

A—Let us erect a steam laundry. The washing (for 100 persons) is now done in a shed and all by hand;
B—Above the laundry to build a common kitchen with dining rooms for boys, girls and staff;
C—As a third story (or second story if laundry is put in a basement) a large sewing room which would also serve the purpose of an auditorium for the children's concerts.

B—We have a farm in connection with the school, the produce of which goes to the upkeep of the school children, and yet, this farm land is taxed by the municipality to the extent of about $1,000.00 per annum or nearly one sixth of our per capita grant. We consider that these taxes should be borne by the Indian Department.

C—A barn is urgently needed but the school has no funds with which to erect it, so practically the entire Government grant each year and all the produce of the farm go to the support and education of the Indian children, who after all, are the wards of the Government. Would the Department be willing to vote us $5,000.00 towards a new barn?

D—When I have explained to Mr Duncan Scott who has always shown great interest in the welfare of our Indians, how by a small outlay, the class-rooms, play-rooms and dormitories could be enlarged, and provision be easily made for 20 or 30 more pupils. Large class-rooms are much needed at the camp where we have so much rain.

E—Lastly, I am making an appeal in behalf of the Indian School in North Vancouver. The Department in all fairness should give them additional help or build them a new school. At present the children and the Sisters are packed like the proverbial sardines. For lack of funds they cannot better conditions. As at St Mary's (Mission B.C.) their little garden and orchard are heavily taxed. The per capita grant is barely enough to supply the children and Sisters with food. It is only by appealing to the charity of other institutions that they can make ends meet. These hardworking and self-sacrificing women are the servants of the Government; why should they be forced to beg, in order to be able to carry on their noble work?
