St. Mary's Indian Residential School

UNDER THE DIRECTION OF
The Oblate Fathers

MISSION CITY, B.C.

Founded in 1861 on the banks of the Fraser, St. Mary's School has carried on its work of educating the Indian ever since. For many years it was the only seat of learning in the region and had to open its doors to Indian and White alike. In course of time schools for the whites were built, but St. Mary's, instead of ceasing to exist, only specialized its course the better to suit the special needs of the Indian.

Thus it carried on, at first without aid from the Government at all, then receiving Sixty Dollars per annum per capita for board, tuition, clothing, and transportation to and from the School, and not infrequently the same sum had to provide a bonus to the parent who thought he should receive something for permitting the School to educate his child.

In 1884, new buildings were constructed on a higher level, and these have been enlarged and replaced as need arose. By 1925 two new separate Class-rooms had been erected. Likewise, the per capita grant, as well as the pupilage, was raised from time to time, in accordance with conditions, or reduced, as in the case of the recent depression, until the St. Mary's of January 1933 was receiving a per capita grant of One Hundred and Forty-Five Dollars per annum for one hundred and seven Indian Children.

At that time it had in residence one hundred and forty children—not because its authorities liked to act contrariwise to an opinion of the Department that the school had not adequate accommodation for more than one hundred and seven, but because when parents came with their poorly clad and underfed children and pleaded that they might leave them at the school the Fathers could not refuse the youngsters admittance, for they realized that even if it meant comparative overcrowding, every child at the school would be infinitely better housed and better fed than he or she could be in the home such parents could provide.

And so they were caring for twenty-three without compensation whatsoever, and the applications for admittance in September 1933 were coming in in goodly numbers, when, by June, it became apparent that additional accommodation must be provided.

Accordingly the Department was visited and asked if assistance could be given to increase the capacity of St. Mary's School which serves a large district and one in which depression seems to have had specially baneful effects upon the Indians. Though no direct help could be offered, the assurance was given that the Department recognized the need of greater accommodation owing to the large number of Indians to be served by that School, and that an increased pupilage should almost surely follow as a matter of course if the School were enlarged and improved to warrant it.
Building operations were commenced at once and went on unceasingly until just before Christmas 1932. Meanwhile a new building was erected, the dimensions of which are fifty by eighty feet. This building is of frame construction stuccoed and plastered, erected on a ten inch concrete foundation.

It has a full basement eight feet high, four feet above ground which furnishes ample space for kitchen store room, ice plant, dairy, quarters for dairyman and technical instructor, and technical class rooms, twenty-four by sixty-four and sixteen by twenty-four respectively. The main floor provides a spacious kitchen, a scullery, and four well-lighted and airy dining rooms, while the top floor is a dormitory with room for more than fifty children. The main floor rooms are ten feet high and the dormitory nine.

The fact of the new building furnishing a central kitchen and dining-rooms makes it possible to turn the former kitchen, dining-rooms and scullery of each residence to other uses. The space thus gained in the girls' residence permitted alterations which give larger sewing rooms, recreation halls, and dormitories, and in the boys', a large well-appointed infirmary, gymnasium, and additional dormitory space.

The boys' residence has been repaired and altered to such an extent that it serves its purpose now much better than it ever did. The girls' residence so far has not been completely done over but the early Spring will see work on it continued. The aim is to have St. Mary's, the first School in point of time in the Province, the first School in point of excellence under the Department of Indian Affairs.

St. Mary's is serving the Indians and they appreciate it. This appreciation was evidenced in a tangible way recently by a bequest of one of its earliest graduates whose life savings made possible the building and repairing operations begun last Summer.

Appreciated because it has provided for a great need, and loved because of its homelike atmosphere and beautiful surroundings, St. Mary's reason for existing is greater today than at any period in the past. There have been times when Indian parents could look after their children at home from the material point of view, the missionary could see to the spiritual, and the day-schools provide the educational needs in many localities, but now poor parents are hampered by Provincial Game and Fishing Laws and innumerable regulations which render them incapable of clothing and feeding their little ones, and the children either go to school improperly and inadequately clad, unable to do justice to school work because of hunger pangs, or else they must idle away their days at home.

Though I took a very decided stand in September, and determined to limit the number of admissions to the pupilage allowed by the Department, I was forced to yield to the sheer pressure of unusual circumstances and at present one hundred and thirty-seven children are in attendance. But over a hundred others are clamouring for admission. Most of these have applied in writing on the regular forms provided by the Department.

Of those admitted over and above the School's pupilage, and of those who have applied now for admission, the greatest number from any one place is from Pemberton Meadows. This is a very low and quite unhealthy place.
spot, an undesirable site for a day school, and yet the centre of a large band of Indians. They are a well-organized band and have great attachment for St. Mary's School. Two families with five children in all of school age have literally camped on the School property for months seeking admission. Before Christmas I yielded to the extent of taking the oldest of the family with the majority.

We are desirous now, as in the past, to provide for the needs of all, but the debts incurred by the improvements already made make it quite impossible for us to carry any longer a greater number than is provided for by per capita grant. The school inspector and the agent have visited the school recently. They agree that we have done all that could be expected, more than actually was expected, to meet the requirements and provide accommodations for the Indian children of our districts, and we now humbly request the Department to increase the pupilage of our School to two hundred and twenty, for we believe we have ample space and accommodation for that number.

Dear Sir:

Honourable and dear Mr. Crerar:

I beg to call to your attention a matter concerning some of the little Indian children of this Province.

Since 1860, the Oblate Fathers have conducted a Residential School at St. Mary's Mission, (now Mission City, B.C.), where the educational needs of the Indian children of the district have been attended to.

From time to time, increased accommodation was called for and provided, and each such increase, from the period when the Government began to allow grants for the education of its wards, met with the approval and sanction of the Government under which it was effected; increased pupilage followed as a matter of course, the increase being to the full capacity of the school so long as there were children to be educated.

Latterly, however, it has not been thus. In 1933, the St. Mary's Mission School authorities approached the Department for increased accommodation. Both parties recognized the need of this, but the Department declared its inability to help financially towards construction while it agreed that, as in the past, increased accommodation would merit and receive corresponding increase in grant-earning pupilage.

Accordingly as the accepted pupilage in 1933 was only 107 and the number of children in the district well over 200, alterations and additions were made at St. Mary's School to provide for 220 children. The work done at that time, met with the approval and high commendation of the Departmental authorities, yet, in 1934, an increase in pupilage of but 18 was granted. Redoubled efforts in 1935 resulted in an additional increase of 25, and so far this year no encouragement has been offered, no assurance given and but little hope held out that further recognition will be given by the Department to the necessary increased pupilage.

At the present time they are allowed 160 children.

There is a building for the boys and one for the girls; also a new building for dormitory accommodation for the male members of the staff and a number of the older boys.

Previous to the carrying out of the above work, per capita grant was provided for 107 pupils. This was increased, in the Estimates for 1934-35, to provide for a pupilage to a total of 125. In the Estimates for 1935-36, provision was made for a further increase of 25 pupils - thus providing for a total of 150 as from April first, 1935. The church authorities have been urging since that time for a grant for the full number

- of pupils
of pupils which the school will accommodate. Owing to definite instructions, that no increases were to be made in our Estimates for the coming fiscal year, 1936-37, it was not possible to provide for a further number of pupils. The last returns from the school show that there are actually 162 children in attendance, and, as this school is situated in the vicinity of a number of reserves of Catholic Indians, there would be no difficulty in recruiting to the full number for which accommodation can be provided. I understand that many applications have to be refused by the school authorities.

It would, no doubt, be possible, from the appropriation for per capita grants for the coming fiscal year, to find funds to provide for an increase of 10 pupils, and the amount required would be as follows:

10 pupils @ $170 per capita = $1700.

I beg to recommend that a grant for an increase of 10 pupils, as from January 1st, 1936, be provided, to the amount of $1700, less the present deductions. If this extra number is allowed, it would provide a grant for a total of 160 children. If the Superintendent General and yourself concur, a letter could then be drafted for his signature to the Archbishop of Vancouver.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

I wish to call your attention to a very serious matter regarding the pupilage of this school which I hope you will refer to the Department immediately to have settled as soon as possible.

When I was appointed Principal in November I found 160 pupils in attendance with 15 more temporarily absent for one reason or another. I inquired as to the number for whom the Government allowed a per capita grant and I found it did not exceed 160. Now it is quite impossible to meet the expenses of the School with the grant for that number. The daily allowance for each child is barely sufficient to provide food, clothing, fuel and other necessary expenses. How then am I to provide for those children for whom the Government allows nothing?

I am therefore forced either to provide those children with insufficient food and clothing or to discharge them. I can not and will not do the first. Any children kept in the School must be properly taken care of. Nor can I discharge them. Many of these same children are weak and sickly and need medical attention and special care which could not be given to them on the Reserves. Were they allowed to return to the Reserves a good number of them would die.

Furthermore have not those children the same right to receive proper education and training? Are they not wards of the Government which should find means to provide for them and to educate them to become true Canadian citizens?

The only solution to the problem is to have the grant increased at least to 185. That would be sufficient to provide for the number already in School and for a few of the many who are making application to enter. There are more than fifty children whose parents are most anxious that they be admitted to School as soon as possible.

The Oblate Fathers made provision, within the last few years, for at least 215 children. In the past the Government allowed an increase in the grant where increased accommodation was provided. But for the present if you could prevail upon the Department to increase the grant by 25 I should feel enabled to meet the financial expenses of the School which, with the grant as it is now, are overburdening.

With kindest regards I am

Welfare & Training -

The St. Mary's Indian Residential School continues to do wonderful work in training its pupils for future life. The boys are given a thorough manual training on practical lines, and are carefully trained in farming as well. The girls receive a similar instruction in home economics, including both needlework and cooking. A great deal of very useful instruction has been given them in the art of making over garments, by the adaptation of military uniforms to ordinary civilian requirements. This school also believes in the character forming quantities of Athletic and Gymnastic instruction, and has gone far in this respect. The various school teams have an enviable record in various fields of sport, and their gymnastic teams have gained laurels not only in the local valley towns, but in Vancouver itself. About sixty boys make up five teams. This physical activity has had a wonderful effect on the boys, and has greatly advanced the mental and moral standard of these young people. Mr. J. Matheson, Provincial Director of the Pro-Rec. in a recent broadcast spoke in glowing terms of the work being performed by the school in this direction. The boys of this School will compete in the Provincial Gymnastic competition this Spring. The disciplinarian at the School this year, is Thomas Bull, a former pupil and outstanding athlete.

A. O'N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.
St. Mary's Indian Residential School: The Reverend A.H. Fleury, O.M.I., is Principal of this School, which has a roll of 200 pupils, 94 boys and 106 girls. Their health has been excellent throughout the year. Conditions at the School are very good, and it is very popular with the Indians. Inspector's reports are invariably good, the children happy, and in every way this school is outstanding. It has made quite a name for itself in the Pro. Rec. and Athletic field as well.

In addition to the actual School Work, the Reverend Principal co-operates with the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital by carrying a number of convalescent children from that Institution in his Preventorium, which is in the charge of a Registered Nurse. Many of these children had had no previous connection with the School or Agency. This releases hospital beds, while the children receive convalescent care they would not receive at their homes.

A. O'N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM:

- THE DEPUTY MINISTER -

I am sending forward herewith copies of correspondence between this branch and Major Ian Eisenhardt, National Director of Physical Fitness. The subject matter of this correspondence, you will note, is self-explanatory.

It would appear that Major Eisenhardt visited St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Mission, British Columbia, about two years ago, and while there, succeeded in interesting the boys in a physical fitness campaign. Major Eisenhardt reports that the boys have made phenomenal progress and at the moment excel to a greater extent than any other group of whom he has knowledge in gymnastics, folk dancing, etc. He is so impressed by the work of these boys that he now proposes to take them on a tour of the Dominion and to have a film made of their exercises at an approximate cost of $5,000.00. When the matter was discussed with me first, it was my understanding that the full cost would be borne by the Department of National Health and Welfare, but it now transpires that their funds are somewhat limited, hence the request to this Branch for a 50% contribution. While no provision has been made in our estimates for such an expenditure and while the expenditure itself is somewhat substantial, conversations I have had with Major Eisenhardt have convinced me that the project is well worthwhile and should prove invaluable from a publicity standpoint. This film displayed on other reserves should prove of great educational value, particularly along the lines of health and physical development. The amount of $2,500.00 might be included in a supplementary estimate or paid from our welfare funds with the approval of the Minister. Your comments on this proposal would be appreciated.

Director.

SUBJECT: Proposed Canadian Tour

Participants: Proposed 15 Indian boys from the St. Mary's Indian Residential School and 15 Pro-Rec women and 15 Pro-Rec men. Party headed by Major Ian Eisenhardt, accompanied by Reverend Father A. H. Fleury, Mrs. Keatley, Tommy Ruben, Sid Greenwood and Jerry Mathisen.

Itinerary: One club car and one colonist car. Girls to be in the club car and men in the colonist car. List of demonstrations proposed for the following cities; the final dress rehearsal at St. Mary's School. Send off from Vancouver, then Calgary, Regina, Winnipeg, Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal, Caughnawaga, Quebec City, Halifax, Charlottetown, Debert, Fredericton, St. John, Three Rivers, Montreal, Ottawa, Hamilton, Oshawa, Windsor, Fort William, Brandon, Saskatoon, Edmonton, Vancouver and Mission.

It was proposed to have an afternoon performance wherever possible for school children at a popular price of 10¢ and evening performances at 25¢ and 50¢. Major Eisenhardt outlined suggestions for programme. All programmes to open with the Grand March and O'Canada. Introduction by the National Director. It was suggested further that the Indian section be given a block section in the programme. Father Fleury mentioned that slacks would have to be used for the girls in Quebec. A list of uniforms will include slacks, blazers, berets, tie and the required number of gymnastic uniforms. Souvenir programme will be printed in which it was suggested that a greeting be given by the National Director and by the representative Provincial Governments.

Initial step—Major Eisenhardt will undertake to obtain permission, arrange for transportation, arrange for advertising in the form of pictures, films etc., make all arrangements required from the Government point of view.; Arrange for auditor to take charge of the cash. Father Fleury to make all church contacts and outline necessary rules to conform with proper church conduct such as stopping Sunday morning for Mass, etc.

As soon as Major Eisenhardt has obtained the necessary permission in Ottawa permission is to be obtained by Mr. Mathisen from the Honourable Mr. Perry. Mr. Mathisen to contact C.P.E.A. and notify teachers. Committees should be formed in each City where the demonstration is to be put on.
DEMONSTRATION BY INDIAN BOYS AND GIRLS
ST. MARY'S INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
MISSION CITY, B.C.

On Wednesday morning, April 11th, a mass display of fundamental and advanced gymnastics was put on by a group of sixty boys from St. Mary's Indian School, under the direction of T. Ruben, instructor.

Present for the display was the Federal Director for Canada of The National Fitness Program, Major Ian Eisenhardt, Captain Darby, Saskatchewan Physical Education Director, Wray Youmans, Manitoba Physical Education Director, Jerry Mathisen, B.C. Pro-Rec Director, Mr. A. O.M. Daunt, Indian Agent, Miss Lillian Dynes and Rev. A. H. Fleury, C.I., Principal of the St. Mary's School.

The boys went through a program of rhythmic exercises, then were divided into three groups of gymnastic teams. Two of these groups displayed fundamental tumbling and springboard work. The third group of seniors gave an advanced display of tumbling, high vaulting, springboard and parallel bar work, finishing off with two-man pitching and tossing.

At the close the girls of the School sang and Major Eisenhardt addressed them. He complimented the children and their instructors on their fine performances. He also announced that he would arrange for the National Film Board to visit the School to take a film of the display, to be shown across Canada, as he considered it the finest exhibition of gymnastics that he had seen from such young people.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

It is my duty to call your attention to a situation that has been prevalent for some years in the district and territory served by St Mary's Indian Residential School.

This institution has an authorized quota of 175 pupils and serves the two Agencies of New Westminster and Lytton. There are, in these two Agencies, according to the Government Census of 1939, 629 Catholic children of school age. Beside St Mary's boarding school, there are four Catholic Day Schools operating in these two Agencies with a maximum enrollment of 110 pupils. Also about 85 children attend other Residential Schools. This leaves about 434 children to be taken care of by St Mary's. Considering the fact that our quota is 175, this means that about 80% of the Catholic children of these two Agencies are without the means of Catholic schooling. You will admit with me that this is a very alarming situation, both from the point of view of the Department and the Church. It is all the more striking when you consider that most of these children live in the Fraser Valley, a thickly populated and progressive district. In such surroundings, lack of education is a serious handicap.

In an effort to relieve this situation, St Mary's School has been carrying a considerable number over its quota of 175 as there is room for 210 children at the school. This is not fair, you will admit, to the school but the pressure of applications has been so great, especially

......2
to Mr. R. E. Hoey --

in regard to destitute children, that we could hardly refuse sympathetic aid to the requests of Agents and parents. There are present, today, at St Mary's 97 boys and 105 girls. This represents 28 over our quota.

I am informed that this situation has now existed for over five years and that the Principal has carried that extra number without receiving any relief from the Department of Indian Affairs.

In view of the above facts, I will ask you to authorize an increase for this school from the present number of 175 to 210. This increase will enable us to take a few more pupils over the number that we have in already and will facilitate the operation of the school.

While the above increase will not solve the Indian problem in the territory served by St Mary's it will at least enable the Principal to carry on with less anxiety and fewer financial troubles. The matter of providing school accommodation for the 200 odd children who are at the present time without school facilities may be left to some future plans which may be evolved between St Mary's and your Department.

Hoping that you will give this matter your immediate attention, I remain,

Very truly yours,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

MEMORANDUM:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

I am sending forward herewith a request for an increase in the authorized enrolment at the Sacred Heart Indian Residential School, Pelican, Alberta, and St. Mary's Mission Indian Residential School, New Westminster, British Columbia.

In this connection, may I refer to Mr. Jackson's memorandum of November 2nd, in which he asks if consideration has been given to the establishment of improved Indian Day Schools on the reserves from which Residential School pupils are recruited. The records indicate that an educational survey was undertaken at the Pelican Reserve by Mr. Doucet about three years ago. Mr. Doucet, in his report, states that the condition of the roads on the reserve, the scattered settlements and climatic conditions, in his judgment, render the operation of an Indian Day School impracticable. No educational survey, so far as I am aware, has been made at W'Appello or at St. Mary's Mission at any time since I entered the department. I am of the opinion, however, that the need for thorough educational surveys at Residential Schools and on reserves throughout the Dominion is becoming a matter of considerable urgency. Should such surveys be undertaken, however, at the earliest possible date and should it be decided to establish improved Day Schools on a number of reserves, it is not at all likely that these schools could be established and in operation at any time within the next two years; in the meantime, our Indian Agents in the administration of Family Allowances are called upon to certify that educational facilities are not available for groups of Indian pupils before such pupils or their parents qualify for allowances under the Family Allowance Act.

Inspection St. Mary's Residential School, Mission

Examination of Eyes for Trachoma.

1. St. Mary's Residential School, Mission was visited on 26 Jan. '49 and pupils were all examined for trachoma.

2. The school appears to be ably staffed and well operated from a health standpoint. Buildings though old were clean and well kept.

3. The boys' showers are located in the basement of the boys building and are reached by opening a trapdoor and descending a stairway. The shower room is damp and cold. There is no outside lighting in the room. Draughts result in the room through cracks in the board walls above ground level. Relocation of the bath room is recommended.

4. Children appeared fairly well nourished, though the noon meal was inspected and appeared somewhat meagre. The meal consisted of macaroni soup, bread and a raw carrot. Dinner is served at the school in the evening. One glass of milk per child per day is issued.

5. Results of trachoma examinations were as follows:

   Positive cases 7
   Doubtful cases 2
   Suspects 3

6. Cases treated in the previous year were all negative except one, possibly due to re-infection at home.

7. There were no common towels in use at the school. Dr. McIntyre visited the school with me and has been supplied with a list of pupils for trachoma treatment.

8. The children's teeth were not all being cleaned. Some pupils were not supplied with toothbrushes. The Principal was advised to requisition toothbrushes through the school branch.

(sgd) P. S. Tennant, M.D.,
Regional Superintendent,
Indian Health Services.

Dear Mr. Eisenhardt:

This is a follow up of conversation we had in regards to some Indian boys taking the Physical Ed. Summer Course here in Vancouver in August. At the time of your visit here to the School you were willing to allow these boys the sum of $25.00 weekly during the three weeks Course to cover their expenses. Two of our Indian boys have volunteered to take this Course. One is Tommy Hull, who will be in charge of Physical Education here during the year. He is a fine athlete and a natural leader and should greatly benefit by this Course. The other is Herbert Francis, a graduate of the School and this Fall will be looking after Physical Ed. on the Seabird Island Indian Reserve situated near Agassiz B.C. He was for two years in charge of Physical Ed. here at the School and is an outstanding boy. Tommy is 24 yrs old and Herbert 21. I fully believe that these two boys willingly profit by the Course and should be able later on to carry on this work amongst their own people. Would appreciate an early reply so that I may get word to both these boys.

In regard to Physical Ed. and Recreation in the School. As you know we have had a very thorough and complete Course in this regard for some years. This has comprised Pro-Rec gymnastics; folk dancing; inter-mural sports etc. In order to carry on this Course the School has employed an Indian boy to help along in this work. Likewise the services of Mr. and Mrs. Huben, both Pro-Rec Instructors. Would it be possible to receive some aid towards the salaries we are now paying out to these people to carry on this Course? The Indian employee receives $1000.00 yearly. Mr. and Mrs Huben $100.00 each yearly. Any financial help along this line would be appreciated.

Many thanks for the snaps taken during your visit. The enclosed photo was taken for publication in the Vancouver Province.

Sincerely Yours,

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
